section_path: Introduction
text: # Introduction We consider the almost Mathieu operator acting in $l ^ 2 ({\mathbb Z})$ by the formula $$\label{op:AM} (H_\theta f) _k = f_ {k+1} + f_ {k-1} +2 \lambda \cos (2 \pi (\theta + hk)) f_k, \quad k \in {\mathbb Z},$$ where $\lambda> 0$,  $0 \le \theta <1$, and $0 [op:AM] arises when studying an electron in a crystal submitted to a constant magnetic field when the field is weak, when it is strong, in semiclassical regime etc, see, e.g.,  and references therein. This operator attracts attention of mathematicians as well as physicists thanks to its rich and unusual properties. One of the most difficult and interesting problems is the problem of describing the geometry of the spectrum of $H_ \theta$. During three decades, efforts of many mathematicians have been aimed at proving that for irrational $h$ the spectrum is a Cantor set. Among them are A. Avila, J. Bellissard, B. Helffer, S.Zhitomirskaya, R. Krikorian, Y. Last, J. Puig, B. Simon, J. Sjöstrand and many others, see , where the proof was completed. We mention also  that are ones of the latest papers on the geometry of the spectrum.

section_path: Introduction
text: We consider the almost Mathieu operator acting in $l ^ 2 ({\mathbb Z})$ by the formula $$\label{op:AM} (H_\theta f) _k = f_ {k+1} + f_ {k-1} +2 \lambda \cos (2 \pi (\theta + hk)) f_k, \quad k \in {\mathbb Z},$$ where $\lambda> 0$,  $0 \le \theta <1$, and $0 [op:AM] arises when studying an electron in a crystal submitted to a constant magnetic field when the field is weak, when it is strong, in semiclassical regime etc, see, e.g.,  and references therein. This operator attracts attention of mathematicians as well as physicists thanks to its rich and unusual properties. One of the most difficult and interesting problems is the problem of describing the geometry of the spectrum of $H_ \theta$. During three decades, efforts of many mathematicians have been aimed at proving that for irrational $h$ the spectrum is a Cantor set. Among them are A. Avila, J. Bellissard, B. Helffer, S.Zhitomirskaya, R. Krikorian, Y. Last, J. Puig, B. Simon, J. Sjöstrand and many others, see , where the proof was completed. We mention also  that are ones of the latest papers on the geometry of the spectrum. Among the papers of physicists explaining the cantorian structure of the spectrum, we single out the paper  containing heuristic analysis clear for mathematicians. In the semiclassical approximation, the author has successively described sequences of shorter and shorter spectral gaps, i.e., obtained a constructive description of the spectrum as a Cantor set. According to , the spectrum located on certain intervals of the real line, being “put under a microscope”, looks like the spectrum of the almost Mathieu operator with new parameters. That is why the approach described by Wilkinson is called a renormalization method. Using methods of the pseudodifferential operator theory, B. Helffer and J. Sjöstrand have developed a rigorous asymptotic renormalization method, and turned the heuristic results into mathematical theorems. Let us note that the asymptotic renormalization methods are used when the parameter $h$ can be represented as a continued fraction with sufficiently large elements. Later, V. Buslaev and A. Fedotov suggested the monodromization method, one more renormalization approach that arose when trying to use the Bloch-Floquet theory ideas to study the geometry of the spectrum of difference operators in $L^2(\mathbb R)$. The method was further developed by A.Fedotov and F.Klopp when studying adiabatic quasiperiodic operators. More details can be found in review . The monodromization method can be used for one-dimensional two-frequency difference and differential quasiperiodic operators independently of any assumptions on the continued fraction. If such an equation contains an asymptotic parameter, one can effectively describe the asymptotic geometry of the spectrum. In  we described how to apply the monodromization method to get a constructive asymptotic description of the spectrum as a Cantor set in the case studied by B. Helffer and J. Sjöstrand. The present paper is the first step to a similar constructive asymptotic description in the case of a small coupling constant. Here, we make only the first renormalization. This allows to describe asymptotically a series of the longest spectral gaps. We get asymptotic formulas for the gap centers and lower bounds for the gap lengths. Note that, the number of the gaps we describe can be of the order of $\ln (1/\lambda)$, and the length of the $k$-th gap is roughly of the order of $\lambda^k$. So, it can be difficult to get such results by means of standard perturbation methods. The results we prove in this paper were partially announced in the short note .

section_path: Introduction
text:
Among the papers of physicists explaining the cantorian structure of the spectrum, we single out the paper  containing heuristic analysis clear for mathematicians. In the semiclassical approximation, the author has successively described sequences of shorter and shorter spectral gaps, i.e., obtained a constructive description of the spectrum as a Cantor set. According to , the spectrum located on certain intervals of the real line, being “put under a microscope”, looks like the spectrum of the almost Mathieu operator with new parameters. That is why the approach described by Wilkinson is called a renormalization method. Using methods of the pseudodifferential operator theory, B. Helffer and J. Sjöstrand have developed a rigorous asymptotic renormalization method, and turned the heuristic results into mathematical theorems.  
Let us note that the asymptotic renormalization methods are used when the parameter $h$ can be represented as a continued fraction with sufficiently large elements.  
Later, V. Buslaev and A. Fedotov suggested the monodromization method, one more renormalization approach that arose when trying to use the Bloch-Floquet theory ideas to study the geometry of the spectrum of difference operators in $L^2(\mathbb R)$. The method was further developed by A.Fedotov and F.Klopp when studying adiabatic quasiperiodic operators. More details can be found in review . The monodromization method can be used for one-dimensional two-frequency difference and differential quasiperiodic operators independently of any assumptions on the continued fraction. If such an equation contains an asymptotic parameter, one can effectively describe the asymptotic geometry of the spectrum. In  we described how to apply the monodromization method to get a constructive asymptotic description of the spectrum as a Cantor set in the case studied by B. Helffer and J. Sjöstrand. The present paper is the first step to a similar constructive asymptotic description in the case of a small coupling constant. Here, we make only the first renormalization. This allows to describe asymptotically a series of the longest spectral gaps. We get asymptotic formulas for the gap centers and lower bounds for the gap lengths. Note that, the number of the gaps we describe can be of the order of $\ln (1/\lambda)$, and the length of the $k$-th gap is roughly of the order of $\lambda^k$. So, it can be difficult to get such results by means of standard perturbation methods.  
The results we prove in this paper were partially announced in the short note .

Below $C$ denotes positive constants independent of any parameters, variables and indices, $H$ denotes expressions of the form $Ce^{C/h}$. When writing $a = O (b)$, we mean that $| a | \le C | b |$, and when writing $a=O_H(b)$, we mean that $|a|\le 
e^{C/h} |b|$.  
Furthermore, for $z\in\mathbb C$, we often use the notations $x={\rm Re}\, z$ and $y={\rm Im}\, z$.  
For $v_1,\,v_2\in\mathbb C^2$, we denote by $V=(v_1\;v_2)$ the matrix with the columns $v_{12}$ and $v_2$.

section_path: Main results
text:
# Main results

It is well known, see, for example, , that for the irrational $h$, as a set, the spectrum of the almost Mathieu operator is independent of the parameter $\theta$ and coincides with the spectrum of the Harper operator acting in $L ^ 2 ({\mathbb R})$ by the formula $H \psi(x) = \psi(x + h) + \psi(x-h) +2\lambda \cos(2 \pi x) \psi(x)$. It is a difference Schrödinger operator with a $1$-periodic potential. Below we discuss only it.  
As for the one-dimensional periodic differential operators, for the operator $H$ one can define a monodromy matrix. Here, we describe asymptotics of a monodromy matrix and spectral results obtained by means of these asymptotics.

section_path: Main results / Monodromy matrix
text: ## Monodromy matrix

section_path: Main results / Monodromy matrix
text: ### Let us consider the Harper equation $$\label{eq:harper} \psi (x + h) + \psi (x-h) +2 \lambda \cos (2 \pi x) \psi (x) = E \psi (x), \quad x \in {\mathbb R},$$ where $E \in {\mathbb C}$ is a spectral parameter. Its solution space is invariant with respect to translation by one. Let us fix a basis in the solution space. The corresponding monodromy matrix represents the restriction of the translation operator to the solution space. Equation [eq:harper] is a second order difference equation on $\mathbb R$, and its solution space is a two-dimensional modul over the ring of $h$-periodic functions, see, e.g. . Thus, the monodromy matrix is a $2\times2$ matrix $h$-periodic in $x$. When defining a monodromy matrix, it is convenient to make a linear change of variables, for it to be $1$-periodic. The formal definitions can be found in sections 3.1.1 and 3.1.3. The following two theorems describe the functional structure of one of the monodromy matrices.

section_path: Main results / Monodromy matrix
text:
**Theorem 1**. *In the solution space of [eq:harper], there exists a basis such that the corresponding monodromy matrix is of the form $$\label{firstM} {\mathcal M} (x) = \left (\begin {array} {cc} a -2 \lambda_1 \cos (2 \pi x) & s + t \, e ^ {\textstyle-2 \pi ix} \\{} \\ -s-t \, e ^ {\textstyle 2 \pi ix} & st / \lambda_1 \end {array} \right), \ \ a = \lambda_1 \frac {1-s ^ 2-t ^ 2} {st}, \ \ \lambda_1 = \lambda ^ {\frac1h},$$ where the coefficients $s$ and $t$ are independent of $x$ and meromorphic in $E$.*
This theorem is a part of Theorem 7.3 from  . The basis solutions are minimal entire solutions, i.e., solutions that are entire functions of $z=x+iy$ growing the most slowly as $|y| \to \infty$. These minimal solutions are meromorphic in $E$.
**Remark 1**. It follows from the proof of this theorem that if, for given $h=h_0\in(0,1)$, $\lambda=\lambda_0 \in (0,\infty)$, and $E=E_0\in\mathbb C$, the coefficients $s$ and $t$ are finite, then they are continuous in $(h,\lambda, E)$ in a neighborhood of $(h_0,\lambda_0, E_0)$.
In Section 6, we check
**Theorem 2**. *If for an $E\in {\mathbb R}$ the coefficient $t$ is finite, then, for this $E$, $$\label{eq:s/a} t \in i{\mathbb R}, \quad |s| = \lambda_1 \sqrt {\frac{1+ |t|^ 2}{\lambda_1^2 + |t|^2}},$$ and the zeroth Fourier coefficient of the trace of the monodromy matrix equals $$\label{trace} L = \frac{2i}{t} \sqrt {(1+ | t | ^ 2) ( \lambda_1^2 +| t | ^ 2)} \cos ({\rm arg} \, (is)).$$*

section_path: Main results / Monodromy matrix
text: Relations  [eq:s/a] and [trace] reflect the self-adjointness of the Harper operator.

section_path: Main results / Monodromy matrix
Main results / Monodromy matrix
text: Note that, in the case of this theorem, one has $st/\lambda_1=e^{\frac{2\pi ip}{h}} (1+ O_H(\lambda^\beta))$. The asymptotics of $s$ and $t$ near the points $p=0$ and $p=1/2$ are more complicated. They are described by Theorem 10. To get the asymptotics of $s$ and $t$, we obtain asymptotics of minimal entire solutions to equation [eq:harper] as $\lambda\to0$. For this, first, we construct entire solutions to the auxiliary equations $\psi (x + h) + \psi (x-h) + \lambda e ^ {\mp 2 \pi i x} \psi (x) = E \psi(x)$. Next, in the half-planes ${\mathbb C}_ \pm$ respectively, for sufficiently small $\lambda$, we construct analytic solutions to the Harper equation that are close to the solutions to the auxiliary equations. Finally, with the help of a Riemann-Hilbert problem, we make of these analytic solutions the minimal entire solutions. Our asymptotic method works if $\lambda < e ^ {- c / h}$. If $h$ is so small that $\lambda >> e ^ {- c / h}$, then the asymptotics of the solutions to the Harper equation can be obtained by semiclassical methods, see, e.g., .

section_path: Main results / Spectral gaps
text:
## Spectral gaps The first renormalization of the monodromization method consists in replacing equation   [eq:harper] with *the first monodromy equation* $$\label{eq:M1} \Psi_1(x + h_1) = M_1(x) \Psi_1(x), \quad x \in {\mathbb C}, \qquad h_1 = \{1/h\},$$ where $M_1$ is a monodromy matrix, and $\{\cdot \}$ is the fractional part. Equations [eq:harper] and [eq:M1] simultaneously have pairs of linearly independent solutions such that one solution of a pair decays exponentially as $x\to+ \infty$, and the other decays as $x\to - \infty$, see Corollary 1. This allows to find gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation by studying solutions to the monodromy equation. In section 3.2 we prove
**Theorem 4**. *Let $I\subset {\mathbb R}$ be an open interval. There exists such a constant $C$ independent of $h$ and $E$ that if $$\label{cond:gap} (L/2)^2 \ge (1 + C \lambda_1) (1+ | t | ^ 2), \quad \lambda_1\le | t | \le 1, \qquad \forall E \in I,$$ then $I$ is in a gap of the Harper operator.*
It is useful to compare this theorem with a well-known theorem from the theory of the one-dimensional periodic differential Schrödinger operators. The latter says that the spectrum of a periodic operator is located on the intervals where the absolute value of the trace of a monodromy matrix is less than or equal to two.

section_path: Main results / Spectral gaps
text: It is useful to compare this theorem with a well-known theorem from the theory of the one-dimensional periodic differential Schrödinger operators. The latter says that the spectrum of a periodic operator is located on the intervals where the absolute value of the trace of a monodromy matrix is less than or equal to two. Using Theorem 4, formula [trace] and the asymptotics $s$ and $t$ described in Theorem 3, one can describe a sequence of the longest gaps in the spectrum of the Harper operator. As its spectrum is symmetric with respect to zero, and as the spectra for the frequencies $h$ and $1-h$ coincide, we consider only the spectrum located on ${\mathbb R}_+$ in the case where $0 **Theorem 5**. *Let $h\in(0,1/2)$ and $\beta\in (0,1/2)$. Let $\lambda \le e ^ {-c / h}$ with a sufficiently large $c$. There exist points $E_k>0$,  $1\le k\le K$,  $K= [1/2h]$, such that $$% E_k = 2 \cos (\pi h k + O_H(\lambda^p)),$$ and, if $1\le k\le K-1$ or if $k=K$ and $[1/h]$ is odd, then the point $E_k$ is located inside a gap $g_k$. The length of $g_k$ satisfies the estimate $$\label{eq:gk} | g_k | \ge 4\left(\frac{\lambda}4\right)^{k} \; \frac {(1+ O_H(\lambda^\beta))} {\sin ^ 2 (\pi h) \sin ^ 2 (2 \pi h) \dots \sin ^ 2 (\pi h (k-1))}$$ where for $k = 1$ the product of the sines has to be replaced with one. If $[1/h]$ be even, and $\lambda^{h_1} \le e ^ {-c / h}$, then the point $E_K$ also is located in a gap $g_K$, and the length of $g_K$ satisfies [eq:gk] with $\beta$ replaced with $p=\min\{h_1,\beta\}$.*

section_path: Main results / Spectral gaps
text: In the next paper, we will prove that the expression in the right hand side of [eq:gk] is the leading term of the asymptotics of the length of the $k$th gap. Theorem 5 agree well with the results of computer calculations described in . The $K$th gap in the case where where $[1/h]$ is even is the most difficult to describe. For small $h h_1$, it is located near zero that is a very special point. For $h\not\in\mathbb Q$, the complexity of the spectrum near zero is well-known. One can find a series of new results in . The right hand side in [eq:gk] equals $\lambda^ke^{O(1/h)}$, see Corollary 4. Therefore, if $\lambda$ is small, and $h$ is of the order of $\frac1{|\ln\lambda|}$, then $|g_K|$, the length of the gap closest to zero, is of the order of $\lambda^{|\ln\lambda| +O(1)}$. So, it can be rather difficult to compute $|g_K|$ using standard perturbation methods. According to , for the almost Mathieu equation with $\lambda<1$ and Diophantine frequencies, as the gap number, say, $k$ tends to infinity, the gap lengths are bounded from above and below by expressions of the form $C(\lambda,h,\epsilon) \lambda^{(1\pm \epsilon)k}$, where $\epsilon$ is a fixed positive number.[^1] And as we mentioned, in our case, one has $|g_k|\ge\lambda^ke^{O(1/h)}$.

section_path: Main results / Spectral gaps
text: According to , for the almost Mathieu equation with $\lambda<1$ and Diophantine frequencies, as the gap number, say, $k$ tends to infinity, the gap lengths are bounded from above and below by expressions of the form $C(\lambda,h,\epsilon) \lambda^{(1\pm \epsilon)k}$, where $\epsilon$ is a fixed positive number.[^1] And as we mentioned, in our case, one has $|g_k|\ge\lambda^ke^{O(1/h)}$. It is interesting to compare our results with the results obtained in the case of small $h$ and $\lambda = 1$, see . In this case, there is a statement similar to Theorem 4. However, the asymptotics of the coefficients $t$ and $s$ turn out to be quite different, and, on the most of the interval $[-4,4]$ containing the spectrum, $L(E)$ oscillates with an amplitude that is exponentially large with respect to $h$ , whereas in our case, for most $E \in (0,2)$, one has $L\approx 2 \cos (p / h)$. Thus, in the case of small $h$, the spectrum is located on a series of exponentially small intervals, and in the case of small $\lambda$, we observe small gaps in the spectrum.

section_path: Main results / Other gaps
text: ## Other gaps Since the matrix $M_1$ is $1$-periodic, for equation [eq:M1], we can also define a monodromy matrix $M_2$ and consider the second monodromy equation that can be obtained from the first one by replacing $M_1$ with $M_2$ and $h_1$ with $h_2=\{1/h_1\}$. Continuing, we can construct an infinite sequence of difference equations. In the next paper, studying consequently the equations of this sequence, we will describe consequently series of shorter and shorter gaps. We also obtain upper bounds for the gaps lengths. Note that, to prove Theorem 5, we use only the asymptotics of the coefficients $s$ and $t$ from Theorem 3, i.e., their asymptotics for $E$ being bounded away from $2$. However, the asymptotics of $s$ and $t$ for $E$ close to $2$ are crucial to study the geometry of the spectrum near its edge. All we need to get these asymptotics is prepared when proving Theorem 3, and they are obtained almost like the ones described in this theorem. So, omitting elementary details, we get them in section 7.4.

section_path: Main results / The plan of the paper
text: ## The plan of the paper In section 3, we give the definition of a monodromy matrix, and prove Theorems 4 and 5. For this we use Theorems 1–3. The most of the remaining part of the paper is devoted to the proof of Theorem 3. In section 4, we construct and analyze analytic solutions to the model equation [mu:eq]. In section 5, we show that, in the upper half-plane, there are analytic solutions to the Harper equation that are close to the solutions to the model equation. Recall that the monodromy matrix described in Theorem 1 corresponds to a basis of two minimal entire solutions to the Harper equation. In section 6, we recall the definition of minimal entire solutions and prove Theorem 2. In section 7, for sufficiently small $\lambda$, using the analytic solutions to the Harper equation constructed in section 5, we construct and study the minimal entire solutions, and prove Theorem 3. Section 7.4 is devoted to the asymptotics of $s$ and $t$ for $p$ close to zero (i.e., for $E$ close to 2). In Section 8, we describe the properties of $\sigma_a$ that are used in this paper.

text: # Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results Here we remind the definition of a monodromy matrix, describe relations between solutions to a difference equation with periodic coefficients and solutions to a corresponding monodromy equation, and prove Theorems 4 and 5.

text: ### Definition and elementary properties of a monodromy matrix

heading.title: Definition and elementary properties of a monodromy matrix

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Monodromy matrices and monodromy equation / Definition and elementary properties of a monodromy matrix
text: ### Definition and elementary properties of a monodromy matrix Here, following  we discuss the difference equations of the form $$\label{eq:matrix} \Psi(x + h) = M (x) \Psi (x),$$ where $x$ is a real variable, $M:{\mathbb R}\to SL(2,{\mathbb C})$ is a given 1-periodic function, and $h \in (0,1)$ is a fixed number. Obviously, for any solution $\Psi$ to [eq:matrix], we have $\det \Psi(x + h) = \det \Psi(x)$, $x\in{\mathbb R}$. We call $SL(2,\mathbb C)$-valued solutions to [eq:matrix] fundamental matrix solutions. Note that, to construct a fundamental solution, it suffices to define it arbitrarily on the interval $0< x < h$, and then, to define its values outside of this interval directly with the help of equation [eq:matrix]. It can be shown that $\tilde \Psi \mathbb R\mapsto M_2({\mathbb C})$ is a matrix-valued solution to [eq:matrix] if and only if it can be represented in the form $$\tilde \Psi(x)= \Psi (x) \;p (x), \quad x \in{\mathbb R},$$ where $p:{\mathbb R}\mapsto M_2({\mathbb C})$ is an $h$-periodic function, and $\Psi$ is a fundamental solution. Note that this representation implies that the space of matrix-valued solutions to [eq:matrix] is a module over the ring of $h$-periodic functions. Let $\psi_1,\ \psi_2 : {\mathbb R}\to {\mathbb C}^2$ be two vector-valued solutions to [eq:matrix]. We say that they are linearly independent if $\det(\psi_1,\; \psi_2)$ does not vanish. In this case, a function $\psi: {\mathbb R}\to {\mathbb C}^2$ is a vector-valued solution to [eq:matrix] if and only if it is a linear combination of $\psi_1$ and $\psi_2$ with $h$-periodic coefficients. Let $\Psi$ be a fundamental solution. As $M$ is $1$-periodic, the function $x\mapsto \Psi(x + 1)$ is also a solution to [eq:matrix], and we can write $$\Psi(x + 1) = \Psi (x)\;p (x),\quad p(x + h) = p(x),\qquad x \in{\mathbb R}.$$ The matrix $M_1 (x) = p^t(hx)$, where ${}^t$ denotes transposition, is called the monodromy matrix corresponding to the fundamental solution $\Psi$. Note that, by construction, a monodromy matrix is 1-periodic and unimodular. In early papers, the $h$-periodic matrix $p$ was called the monodromy matrix. It is more convenient to consider $1$-periodic monodromy matrices.

heading.title: Definition and elementary properties of a monodromy matrix

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Monodromy matrices and monodromy equation / Monodromy equation
text:
### Monodromy equation Let $M_1$ be the monodromy matrix corresponding to a fundamental solution $\Psi$ to [eq:matrix]. Let us consider *the first monodromy equation* [eq:M1]. It appears that the behavior of solutions to [eq:matrix] at infinity “copies” the behavior of solutions to [eq:M1]. Let us formulate the precise statement. Let $M$ be a $SL(2,{\mathbb C})$-valued function of real variable, and $h>0$. Let $k\in {\mathbb Z}$ and $x\in {\mathbb R}$. We put $$P_k(M,x,h)= \begin{cases} M(x+h(k-1))\dots M(x+h)M(x),& k\ge 0,\\ M^{-1}(x+ h k)\dots M^{-1}(x-2h)M^{-1}(x-h),& k<0. \end{cases}$$ Clearly, if $\psi\,:\,{\mathbb R}\to {\mathbb C}^2$ satisfies [eq:matrix], then $$% \psi(x+hk)=P_k(M,x,h)\psi(x)$$ One has
**Theorem 6**. * Let $\Psi$ be a fundamental solution to [eq:matrix], and let $M_1$ be the corresponding monodromy matrix. Then, for all $N\in {\mathbb Z}$, $$\begin{gathered} \label{eq_main_renormalization_formulae} P_N(M,h,x)=\Psi(\{x+Nh\})\sigma_2 P_{N_1}(M_1,h_1,x_1)\sigma_2\Psi^{-1}(x),\\ \nonumber N_1=-[\theta+N h],\qquad h_1=\left\{1/h\right\},\qquad x_1=\left\{x/h\right\}, \end{gathered}$$ where $\sigma_2$ is the Pauli matrix $\begin{pmatrix} 0&-i\\ i& 0\end{pmatrix}$.*
In this paper we use

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Monodromy matrices and monodromy equation / Monodromy equation
text: **Corollary 1**. *In the case of Theorem 6, we assume that $\Psi\in L_{loc}^\infty({\mathbb R},SL(2,{\mathbb C}))$, and that $\psi_\pm^{(1)}$ are two vector-valued solutions to the monodromy equation such that $$\label{est:psi1} \|\psi_\pm^{(1)}(\pm x)\|_{{\mathbb C}^2}\le C_0 e^{\mp \varkappa\,x},\quad x\ge 0,$$ with some positive constants $C_0$ and $\varkappa$. Then there are two vector-valued solutions $\psi_\pm^{(0)}$ to equation [eq:matrix] such that $$\label{det:mon} \det \left(\psi_+^{(0)}(x), \psi_-^{(0)}(x)\right)= \det \left(\psi_+^{(1)}(\{x/h\}), \psi_-^{(1)}(\{x/h\})\right),\quad \forall x\in{\mathbb R},$$ $$\label{est:psi0} \|\psi_\pm^{(0)}(\pm x)\|_{{\mathbb C}^2}\le C_1 e^{\mp \varkappa\,h_1 x},\quad \forall x\ge 0,$$ with a positive constant $C_1$.*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Monodromy matrices and monodromy equation / Monodromy equation
text: *Proof.* As $P_N(M, h, x) \Psi(x)=\Psi(x+Nh)$, formula [eq_main_renormalization_formulae] implies that $$\label{eq:cor:renorm} \Psi(x+Nh)\sigma_2=\Psi(\{x+Nh\})\sigma_2 P_{N_1}(M_1,h_1,x_1).$$ Let us define the solutions $\psi_\pm^{(0)}\,:{\mathbb R}\to{\mathbb C}^2$ to [eq:matrix] by the formulas $$\label{def:psi0} \psi_\pm^{(0)}(x)=\Psi(x)\sigma_2\psi_\mp^{(1)}\left(\{x/h\}\right).$$ As $\det\Psi\equiv 1$, relation [det:mon] is obvious. Furthermore, as $x_1=\{x/h\}$, and $N_1=-[x+Nh]$, formulas [def:psi0] and [eq:cor:renorm] lead to the relation $$\psi_\pm^{(0)}(x+Nh)=\Psi(\{x+Nh\})\sigma_2\psi_\mp^{(1)}(x_1-[x+Nh]h_1), \quad N\in {\mathbb Z},$$ that can be rewritten in the form $$\psi_\pm^{(0)}(x)=\Psi(\{x\})\sigma_2\psi_\mp^{(1)}(x_1-[x]h_1), \quad x\in {\mathbb R}.$$ This formula and estimates [est:psi1] imply [est:psi0]. The proof is complete. ◻

text:
## Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4 Let us consider equation [eq:M1] with the matrix $M_1$ described in Theorem 1. Theorem 4, a sufficient condition for $E$ to be in gap, follows from
**Proposition 1**. *In the case of Theorem 4, for all $E\in I$, there exist two vector solutions $\psi_\pm^{(1)}$ to [eq:M1] such that $\det(\psi_+^{(1)}(x),\psi_-^{(1)}(x))$ is a nonzero constant, and, for $x\ge 0$,  $\|\psi_\pm^{(1)}(x)\|_{{\mathbb C}^2}\le Ce^{\mp x\,\ln\frac{|L|}2}$.*
This proposition implies
**Lemma 1**. *In the case of Theorem 4, for any $E\in I$, the only polynomially bounded solution to the Harper equation [eq:harper] is zero.*

heading.title: Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4
text: First, using these proposition and lemma, we prove Theorem 4. Assume that the Harper operator has some spectrum on $I$. As it is a direct integral of the almost Mathieu operators with respect to $\theta$, then, for some $\theta$, the almost Mathieu operator, has a nontrivial spectrum on $I$, and on $I$ almost everywhere with respect to the spectral measure, the almost Mathieu equation $$% f_ {k+1} + f_ {k-1} +2 \lambda \cos (2 \pi (\theta + hk))f_k=Ef_k, \quad k \in {\mathbb Z}.$$ has a polynomially bounded solution $f$ (see section 2.4 in ). One defines a solution $\psi$ to the Harper equation so that $\psi(x)=f_k(\theta)$ if $x=\theta+kh$ with $k\in\mathbb Z$, and $\psi(x)=0$ otherwise. The $\psi$ is a non-trivial polynomially bounded solution to the Harper equation. This contradicts Lemma 1. Now, let us prove Lemma 1 and Proposition 1. *Proof of Lemma 1*.  Let us assume that, for an $E\in I$, there is a nontrivial polynomially bounded solution $\psi$ to [eq:harper]. For this $E$ we construct the solutions to the monodromy equation described in Proposition 1. Then, in terms of these solutions, we construct the solutions $\psi_\pm^{(0)}$ to equation [eq:matrix] with matrix [eq:M:Shcr] as described in Corollary 1 (this is possible as the fundamental solution used to define the monodromy matrix from Theorem 1 is entire in $x$). Let $\psi_1$ be the first entry of $\psi_+^{(0)}$, and $\psi_2$ be the one of $\psi_-^{(0)}$. One has $$\{\psi_1(x),\,\psi_2(x)\}=\det(\psi_+^{(0)}(x),\,\psi_-^{(0)}(x))=\det (\psi_+^{(1)}(x),\,\psi_-^{(1)}(x)),$$ where we used Corollary 1. Thus, by Proposition 1, $\{\psi_1(x),\,\psi_2(x)\}$ is a nonzero constant. Therefore, one has [eq:three-solutions]–[eq:periodic-coef]. Now, it suffices to show that the Wronskians $\{\psi(x),\,\psi_{j}(x)\}$,  $j=1,2$, equal zero. But this is obvious, as these Wronskians are periodic and, on the other hand, $\{\psi(x),\,\psi_\pm(x)\}\to 0$ as $x\to\pm \infty$ since $\psi$ is polynomially bounded, and $\psi_\pm$ are exponentially decreasing as $x\to\pm \infty$. The proof of Lemma 1 is complete. 0◻

text:

For this $E$ we construct the solutions to the monodromy equation described in Proposition 1. Then, in terms of these solutions, we construct the solutions $\psi_\pm^{(0)}$ to equation [eq:matrix] with matrix [eq:M:Shcr] as described in Corollary 1 (this is possible as the fundamental solution used to define the monodromy matrix from Theorem 1 is entire in $x$). Let $\psi_1$ be the first entry of $\psi_+^{(0)}$, and $\psi_2$ be the one of $\psi_-^{(0)}$. One has $$\{\psi_1(x),\,\psi_2(x)\}=\det(\psi_+^{(0)}(x),\,\psi_-^{(0)}(x))=\det (\psi_+^{(1)}(x),\,\psi_-^{(1)}(x)),$$ where we used Corollary 1. But this is obvious, as these Wronskians are periodic and, on the other hand, $\{\psi(x),\,\psi_\pm(x)\}\to 0$ as $x\to\pm \infty$ since $\psi$ is polynomially bounded, and $\psi_\pm$ are exponentially decreasing as $x\to\pm \infty$. The proof of Lemma 1 is complete. 0◻ Now, let us prove Proposition 1.
*Proof.* Below we assume that $E\in I$, and that conditions [cond:gap] are satisfied. In view of Theorem 1, we can represent the monodromy matrix in the form $$\label{eq:MMM} M_1(x)=M_1^0+\tilde M(x), \quad \tilde M(x)=O(t), \qquad M_1^0=\begin{pmatrix} \frac{\lambda_1}{st}(1-s^2-t^2) & s \\ -s & \frac{st}{\lambda_1} \end{pmatrix}.$$ The plan of the proof is the following. First, we transform the monodromy equation with a matrix $M_1$ of the form [eq:MMM] to the equation $$\label{eq:phi} \phi(x+h)=p \left(D+\Delta(x)\right)\,\phi(x), \quad D=\begin{pmatrix} 1/U & 0 \\ 0 & U\end{pmatrix},\qquad x\in{\mathbb R},$$ where $p$ and $U$ are parameters, and $\Delta$ is a “sufficiently small” matrix. Then, we construct two solutions to [eq:phi] by means of

heading.title: Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4
text: **Proposition 2**. *Let us consider equation [eq:phi] with parameters $h>0$, $p\ge 1$ and $U\in \mathbb R$, and a function $p\left(D+\Delta\right) \in L^\infty({\mathbb R},SL(2,{\mathbb C}))$. Let $$\label{f-d-e-on-R1} |U+U^{-1}|> 2, \quad\text{and}\quad |U-U^{-1}|> 4m, \qquad m=\max_{1\leq i,j\leq 2}\sup_{x\in{\mathbb R}}|\Delta_{ij}(x)|.$$ There exist $\phi_\pm \in L^{\infty}_{\rm loc} ({\mathbb R},{\mathbb C}^2)$, vector-valued solutions to [eq:phi], such that $$\label{est:phi} \|\phi_\pm(\pm x)\|_{{\mathbb C}^2}\le Ce^{ \mp \frac{x}h\ln\frac{p|U+U^{-1}|}2} \ \ \forall x\ge 0,\qquad \inf_{x\in {\mathbb R}}|\det(\phi_+(x),\phi_-(x))|>0.$$*

heading.title: Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4

text: Mutatis mutandis, the proof of Proposition 2 repeats the proof of Proposition 4.1 from  where we have considered the case of $p=1$. The $\det(\phi_+,\phi_-)$ being $h$-periodic, the function $x\mapsto \phi_+(x)/\det(\phi_+(x),\phi_-(x))$ satisfies [eq:phi]. We keep for this new function the old notation $\phi_+$. It belongs to $L^{\infty}_{\rm loc} ({\mathbb R},{\mathbb C}^2)$, satisfies estimate [est:phi], and we have $\det(\phi_+(x),\phi_-(x))=1$. To complete the proof of Proposition 1, we return from [eq:phi] to the monodromy equation constructing $\psi_\pm^{(1)}$ in terms of $\phi_\pm$.

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4
text: Mutatis mutandis, the proof of Proposition 2 repeats the proof of Proposition 4.1 from  where we have considered the case of $p=1$. The $\det(\phi_+,\phi_-)$ being $h$-periodic, the function $x\mapsto \phi_+(x)/\det(\phi_+(x),\phi_-(x))$ satisfies [eq:phi]. We keep for this new function the old notation $\phi_+$. It belongs to $L^{\infty}_{\rm loc} ({\mathbb R},{\mathbb C}^2)$, satisfies estimate [est:phi], and we have $\det(\phi_+(x),\phi_-(x))=1$. To complete the proof of Proposition 1, we return from [eq:phi] to the monodromy equation constructing $\psi_\pm^{(1)}$ in terms of $\phi_\pm$. Let us transform the monodromy equation to the form [eq:phi]. Therefore, we compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of $M_0$. In view of Theorem 2, one has $$% t=i\tau,\quad \tau\in{\mathbb R},\qquad s=-i\lambda_1\sqrt{\frac{1+\tau^2}{\tau^2+\lambda_1^2} }\;e^{i\alpha}, \quad \alpha\in {\mathbb R},$$ Let $$% p=\sqrt{1+\tau^2}, \quad q=\frac1\tau\sqrt{\tau^2+\lambda_1^2},\quad Q=\sqrt{q^2\cos^2\alpha-1}.$$ Then $$% {\rm tr}\,M_1^0=L=2pq \cos\alpha,\qquad \det M_1^0=p^2.$$ The eigenvalues $\nu_\pm$ and the corresponding eigenvectors $v_\pm$ are given by the formulae $$\begin{gathered} % \nu_\pm= p\left(q\cos\alpha \pm Q\right),\quad v_\pm=\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -\frac{p}s \left( q\cos\alpha-\frac1qe^{i\alpha}\mp Q\right) \end{pmatrix}.

heading.title: Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 4
text: Let us transform the monodromy equation to the form [eq:phi]. Therefore, we compute the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of $M_0$. In view of Theorem 2, one has $$% t=i\tau,\quad \tau\in{\mathbb R},\qquad s=-i\lambda_1\sqrt{\frac{1+\tau^2}{\tau^2+\lambda_1^2} }\;e^{i\alpha}, \quad \alpha\in {\mathbb R},$$ Let $$% p=\sqrt{1+\tau^2}, \quad q=\frac1\tau\sqrt{\tau^2+\lambda_1^2},\quad Q=\sqrt{q^2\cos^2\alpha-1}.$$ Then $$% {\rm tr}\,M_1^0=L=2pq \cos\alpha,\qquad \det M_1^0=p^2.$$ The eigenvalues $\nu_\pm$ and the corresponding eigenvectors $v_\pm$ are given by the formulae $$\begin{gathered} % \nu_\pm= p\left(q\cos\alpha \pm Q\right),\quad v_\pm=\begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ -\frac{p}s \left( q\cos\alpha-\frac1qe^{i\alpha}\mp Q\right) \end{pmatrix}. \end{gathered}$$ Let $V=(v_+\;v_-)$. We represent a vector-valued solution to [eq:M1] in the form $$\label{eq:psi-phi} \psi(x)= V\phi(x).$$ Then $\phi$ satisfies equation [eq:phi] with $$\label{eq:theta-Delta} U=q\cos\alpha +Q \quad \text{and} \quad \Delta(x)=\frac1p\,V^{-1} \tilde M(x)V.$$ Let us determine the conditions under which $U$ and $\Delta$ from [eq:theta-Delta] satisfy the assumptions of Proposition 2. Let $$\label{eq:cond1} q^2\cos^2\alpha>1.$$ We can and do assume that $Q>0$ and consider the case where $q\cos\alpha>1$. The complementary case is analyzed similarly. We have $U>1$, and the first condition in [f-d-e-on-R1] is satisfied. Now, let us estimate the entries of $\Delta$. One has $$|\sin\alpha|=\sqrt{1-\cos^2\alpha}\le \sqrt{1-\frac1{q^2}}\le \left|\frac{\lambda_1}\tau\right|,\quad Q=\sqrt{\left(1+\frac{\lambda_1^2}{\tau^2}\right)\cos^2\alpha-1} \le\left|\frac{\lambda_1}\tau\right|.$$ Therefore and as $\lambda_1\le |\tau|$, the second entries of $v_\pm$ are uniformly bounded : $$\left|\frac{p}s \left( q\cos\alpha-\frac1qe^{i\alpha}\mp Q\right)\right| =\left|\frac{p}{qs}\right|\left|\frac{\lambda_1^2}{\tau^2}\cos\alpha- i\sin\alpha\mp qQ\right|\le C\left|\frac{p\lambda_1}{qs\tau}\right|=C.$$ As $\det V=-2pQ/s$, this estimate implies that, for all $i,j\in\{1,2\}$, $$% \max_{x\in{\mathbb R}} |\Delta_{ij}(x)|\le C\left|\frac{s\tau}{p^2Q}\right|= C\left|\frac{\lambda_1}{pqQ}\right|< C\frac{\lambda_1}{Q}.$$ Therefore, the second condition from [f-d-e-on-R1] is satisfied if $$\label{eq:phi:1} \frac{U-U^{-1}}2=Q\ge C\frac{\lambda_1}{Q} \quad \Longleftrightarrow\quad q^2\cos^2\alpha\ge 1+C\lambda_1.$$ Clearly, this condition implies [eq:cond1] and, as $L=2pq\cos\alpha$, it is equivalent to [cond:gap]. Let assume that [eq:phi:1] is satisfied. Then, using Proposition 2 and formula [eq:psi-phi], we construct two vector-valued solutions $\psi_\pm=V\phi_\pm$ to the monodromy equation. As $p(U^{-1}+U)/2=pq\cos\alpha=L/2$, estimates [est:phi] imply the estimates for $\psi_\pm$ from Proposition 1. Furthermore, one has $$\det(\psi_+(x),\psi_-(x))= \det V\,\det(\phi_+(x),\phi_-(x))=\det V\ne 0.$$ The proof is complete. ◻

text:
## Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 Theorem 5 describing a sequence of gaps in the spectrum of the Harper operator follows from Theorem 4, a sufficient condition for $E$ to be in a gap written in terms of the coefficients $s$ and $t$ of a monodromy matrix, and Theorem 3 describing the asymptotics of the monodromy matrix as $\lambda\to0$. Below we assume that $$% p\in I_p=[h/4,\; 1/4].$$ where $p$ is the parameter related to $E$ by [def:p]. In view of [trace], condition [cond:gap] can be written in the form $$\label{cond:gap:1} (1+X^2)\cos^2\alpha\ge 1+C_0\lambda_1, \quad X=\lambda_1/\tau=i\lambda_1/t,$$ where $\alpha=\arg{is}$,  $s$ and $t$ being the coefficients from Theorem 1, $\lambda_1=\lambda^{1/h}$, and $C_0$ is a certain positive constant. Below, when analyzing [cond:gap:1], we assume that the following hypothesis is true.
**Hypothesis 1**. *One has $\lambda\le e^{-c_0/h}$, where $c_0>0$ is a sufficiently large constant.*

heading.title: Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5

text: This hypothesis is needed in particular, to use Theorem 3 on the asymptotics of the monodromy matrix coefficients $s$ and $t$. Also, we fix $\beta\in (0,1/2)$.

Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / Locations of gaps
text: *Proof.* Pick $c$ sufficiently small. Let $V_{ch}$ be the $(ch)$-neighborhood of $I_p$. Recall that $F_0$ is given by [def:F0]. The description of the zeros and poles of the function $\sigma_{a}$ from section 8.1.2 implies that in $V_{ch}$ the function $F_0$ is real analytic and does not vanish. Formula [as:alpha] follows from the second formula in [as:st]. As the function $p\mapsto\sin(2\pi p) / F_0 (p)$ from [as:st] is analytic and does not vanish in $V_{ch}$, and as $s$ is meromorphic in $E$, the second formula in [as:st] implies that $s$ is bounded and thus analytic in $p\in V_{ch}$. And the analyticity of $s$ and the same formula imply that the error term in [as:st] is also analytic in $V_{ch}$. The estimate [est:error:alpha] follows from the analyticity of the error term and the Cauchy representation for the derivatives of analytic functions. ◻

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / Locations of gaps
text: **Lemma 3**. *For $p\in I_p$, one has $$\begin{gathered} \label{as:x} X=X_0(p)\left(1+O_H\left(\lambda^\beta\right)\right),\qquad X_0(p)=e^{2p\ln\lambda /h} \frac{2\sin(2\pi p)}{F_0(p)}, \\ \label{est:lnX0} \ln X_0(p)=\frac{2p\ln\lambda}h +O\Big(\frac1h\Big),\qquad \left(O\Big(\frac1h\Big)\right)'_p=O\Big(\frac1h\Big). \end{gathered}$$*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / Locations of gaps
text: *Proof.* Formulas [as:x] follow from Theorem 3. For $p\in I_p$, we get $$\label{eq:lnX0} \ln X_0=\frac{2p\ln\lambda}h-\ln F_0(p) +\ln p+O(1),\quad \frac{d O(1)}{dp}=O(1),$$ where $\ln F_0(p)$ and $\ln p$ are real. It suffices to show that $$\ln F_0(p)=O(1/h),\quad (\ln F_0)(p)=O(1/h),\quad p\in I_p.$$ Let us fix $\delta\in (0,\pi)$. By Corollary 9 we get $$\label{est:f} \ln F(p)=O\left(1/h\right)\quad \text{if}\quad |4\pi p+\pi h|\ge \delta, \ \ -h/4\le {\rm Re}\,p \le 1 \text{ \ and \ }|{\rm Im}\,p|\le 1.$$ This estimate and the Cauchy representations for the derivatives of analytic functions imply that, in any fixed subinterval of the interval $[\delta/4\pi-h/4, 1]$, one has $(\ln F)'(p)=O(1/h)$. However, as $\delta$ is chosen quite arbitrarily, we can write $$\label{est:df} (\ln F)'(p)=O(1/h), \quad \delta/4\pi-h/4\le p\le 1/4.$$ If $\max \{\delta/4\pi-h/4,\;h/4\}\le p\le 1/4$, estimates [est:f], [est:df], [eq:lnX0] imply [est:lnX0]. Let us assume that $|4\pi p +\pi h|\le\delta$ and $p\in I_p$. For $p\in I_p$, one has $2p/h>1/2$. Theorem 12 implies that $$\ln F(p)=\frac{4p\ln h}{h}+2\ln\Gamma\,\Big(\frac{2p}h+1\Big)+ O\Big(\frac1{h}\Big),\quad \left(O\Big(\frac1h\Big)\right)'_p=O\Big(\frac1h\Big),\quad p\in I_p,$$ where the values of the logarithms are real. When deriving this formula, we have estimated the derivative of the error term from [theta:delta] arguing as when proving [est:df]. As $2p/h>1/2$, we estimate $\ln\Gamma(2p/h+1)$ using the Stirling formula $(\ln\Gamma)(x+1)=x(\ln x-1)+O(\ln x)$, where the error term satisfies the estimate $(O(\ln x))_x'=O(1/x)$. We get $$\ln F(p)=\frac{4 p\ln p}{h}+O\Big(\frac1{h}\Big)=O\Big(\frac1{h}\Big),\quad \left(O\Big(\frac1h\Big)\right)'_p=O\Big(\frac1h\Big),\qquad \frac{h}4\le p\le \frac{\delta}{4\pi} -\frac{h}4,$$ and thus, in view of [eq:lnX0], estimate [est:lnX0] . The proof is complete. ◻

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / Locations of gaps
text:

For $p\in I_p$, we get $$\label{eq:lnX0} \ln X_0=\frac{2p\ln\lambda}h-\ln F_0(p) +\ln p+O(1),\quad \frac{d O(1)}{dp}=O(1),$$ where $\ln F_0(p)$ and $\ln p$ are real.
