When deriving this formula, we have estimated the derivative of the error term from [theta:delta] arguing as when proving [est:df]. As $2p/h>1/2$, we estimate $\ln\Gamma(2p/h+1)$ using the Stirling formula $(\ln\Gamma)(x+1)=x(\ln x-1)+O(\ln x)$, where the error term satisfies the estimate $(O(\ln x))_x'=O(1/x)$. We get $$\ln F(p)=\frac{4 p\ln p}{h}+O\Big(\frac1{h}\Big)=O\Big(\frac1{h}\Big),\quad \left(O\Big(\frac1h\Big)\right)'_p=O\Big(\frac1h\Big),\qquad \frac{h}4\le p\le \frac{\delta}{4\pi} -\frac{h}4,$$ and thus, in view of [eq:lnX0], estimate [est:lnX0] . The proof is complete. ◻ Lemma 2 immediately implies
**Corollary 2**. *For $p_k\in I_p$, one has $$\label{as:pk} p_k=\frac{hk}2+O_H\big(\lambda^\beta \big)$$ where the error is uniform uniform in $k$*
One can easily see that, for sufficiently small $\lambda$ $hk/2\in I_p$ if and only if $$\label{eq:k:pk} 1\le k \le K,\quad K=\left[\frac1{2h}\right],$$ where $[x]$ denotes the integer part of $x\in\mathbb R$. We note also that $$% \textstyle\frac14-\frac{hK}2=\frac{h}4\cdot \begin{cases} h_1& \text{\rm \ if \ } [1/h] {\rm \ is \ even},\\ 1+h_1 & \text{\rm \ if \ } [1/h] {\rm \ is \ odd}.\\ \end{cases} %$$ For the points $p_k$ one has
**Corollary 3**. *Let us fix a positive constant $C_1$ so that the error terms in [as:alpha] and [est:error:alpha] be bounded by $\delta_0=\lambda^\beta e^{C_1/h}$. If $\delta_0/\pi \le\min\{1/3,\,h_1/2\}$, and $k$ satisfies [eq:k:pk], then there is $p_k\in I_p$.*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / Locations of gaps
text:
*Proof.* By Lemma 2, the function $\alpha$ is monotonous on the interval $[h/3,\,1/4]$, and $[2\pi/3+\delta_0,\,\pi/(2h)-\delta_0]\subset \alpha\big([h/3,\,1/4]\big)$. Thus, for any $k$ satisfying $$\frac23+\frac{\delta_0}\pi\le k\le \frac1{2h}-\frac{\delta_0}\pi,$$ the equation $\alpha(p_k)=\pi k$ has a unique solution in $[h/3,\,1/4]$. As $\delta_0/\pi\le 1/3$, the the minimal possible value of $k$ equals 1. Recall that $1/h=[1/h]+h_1$,  $h_1\in(0,1)$. Thus, one has $$\frac1{2h}= \begin{cases} \left[\frac1{2h}\right]+\frac{h_1}2, & \text{\rm \ if \ } [1/h] {\rm \ is \ even},\\ \left[\frac1{2h}\right]+\frac{1+h_1}2, & \text{\rm \ if \ } [1/h] {\rm \ is \ odd}, \end{cases}$$ and as $\delta_0/\pi\le h_1/2$, the maximal value of $k$ equals $\left[\frac1{2h}\right]$. The proof is complete. ◻
**Remark 2**. As seen from the proof, either if $\left[\frac1h\right]$ is odd, or if $k< \left[\frac1{2h}\right]$, then the condition on $\delta_0$ can be weakened and replaced with $|\delta_0/\pi|\le 1/2$.
One has
**Lemma 4**. *For any $k=1,2,\dots K-1$, the point $E_k=2\cos(2\pi p_k)$ is located in a gap. The point $E_K$ is in a gap if either $\left[\frac1{h}\right]$ is odd, or $\left[\frac1{h}\right]$ is even, and $\lambda^{h_1}0$ is a certain constant.*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / Locations of gaps
text:
*Proof.* In view of [cond:gap:1] and the definition of $p_k$, see [def:Ek], it suffices to prove that $X(p_k)\ge C_0 \lambda_1$, where $\lambda_1=\lambda^{1/h}$, and $C_0>0$ is certain constant. If the constant $c_0$ in Hypothesis 1 is sufficiently large, then using Lemma 3 and [as:pk], we get $$% \label{eq:Xpk} % X(p_k)=e^{\frac{2p_k\ln\lambda}h+O\left(\frac1h\right)}= e^{k\ln\lambda+O_H(k\lambda^\beta\ln\lambda)+ O\left(\frac1h\right)}=\lambda^k e^{O\left(\frac1h\right)}.\\ %$$ So, $\frac{\lambda_1}{X^2(p_k)}\le\lambda^{\frac1h-2k+\frac Ch}$, and we get $$\label{ineq:lambdaX2} \frac{\lambda_1}{X^2(p_k)}\le e^{\frac Ch}\cdot \begin{cases} \lambda^2 & \text{\rm \ if \ } 1\le k\le K-1, \\ \lambda^{1+h_1} & \text{\rm \ if \ } k=K, \text{\rm \ and \ } \left[\frac1{h}\right] {\rm \ is \ odd}, \\ \lambda^{h_1} & \text{\rm \ if \ } k=K, \text{\rm \ and \ } \left[\frac1{h}\right] {\rm \ is \ even}. \end{cases}$$ This implies the needed. ◻
Below, we denote by $g_k$ the gap containing $E_k$. We have proved the statement of Theorem 5 on the location of $g_k$,  $k=1,2,\dots K$.

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / The lengths of gaps
text:
### The lengths of gaps Here we prove [eq:gk]. Let us fix $1\le k\le K$. To get a lower bound for $|g_k|$, the length of $g_k$, we first assume that $$% |p-p_k|\le ChX(p_k)$$ and prove
**Lemma 5**. *Under hypothesis 1, one has $$\label{eq:AlphaXnearPk} X(p)=X_0(p_k) (1+O_H(\lambda^\beta)),\quad \sin \alpha(p)=\frac{2\pi(p-p_k)}h\;(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta )).$$*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / The lengths of gaps
text:
*Proof.* As when proving Lemma 4, we see that $X(p_k)=\lambda^ke^{O(1/h)}$. Therefore, $$\label{eq:ppk:1} |p-p_k|\le h\lambda^k e^{C/h}.$$ Lemma 3 and [eq:ppk:1] imply that one has $$X(p)=X_0(p)(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta ))= X_0(p_k) e^{\ln \lambda\; \lambda^k e^{C/h}}(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta )).$$ This implies the first formula in [eq:AlphaXnearPk]. Lemma 2 implies that $\alpha(p)=\frac{2\pi (p-p_k)}h\;(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta))$. Thus, in view of [eq:ppk:1], we get $$\sin\alpha=\frac{2\pi (p-p_k)}h \textstyle{\left(1+O\left( \frac{(p-p_k)^2}{h^2}\right)\right)}(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta))= \frac{2\pi (p-p_k)}h(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta)).$$ We proved the second formula in [eq:AlphaXnearPk]. ◻
Now, we can readily prove
**Proposition 3**. *Let $1\le k\le K$, let $\lambda^{h_1}e^{c_0/h}$ be sufficiently small if $k=K$ and $\left[1/h\right]$ is even. Then [cond:gap:2] can be transformed to the form $$\label{cond:gap:3} |p-p_k|\le \frac{h}{2\pi}X_0(p_k)(1+O_H(\lambda^p))$$ where $p=\beta$ if $1\le k\le K-1$ or $\left[1/h\right]$ is odd, and $p=\min\{h_1,\beta\}$ if $k=K$ and $\left[1/h\right]$ is even.*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / The lengths of gaps
text:
*Proof.* The statement follows from Lemma 5 and formulas [eq:Xpk] and [ineq:lambdaX2]. ◻
Now, to complete the proof of [eq:gk], we need to compute $X_0(p_k)$ and to write [cond:gap:3] in terms of $E$. We begin with
**Lemma 6**. *For $1\le k\le K$, one has $$\label{formula:X0pk} X_0(p_k)=\left(\frac{\lambda}4\right)^k \frac{\sin(\pi h k)}{h\,\sin^2(\pi h k)\dots \sin^2(\pi h)} (1+O_H(\lambda^\beta)).$$*

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / The lengths of gaps
text: *Proof.* By the second estimate in [est:lnX0], $$\textstyle X_0(p_k)=X_0\left(\frac{hk}2\right)\,(1+O_H(\lambda^\beta))$$ as $\beta$ in Lemma 3 can be chosen greater then in this lemma. Let us recall that $X_0$ is defined in [as:x] with $F_0$ given by [def:F0]. Using [eq:sigma] and [sigma:res], we get $$\textstyle F_0\left(\frac{hk}2\right)= \prod_{\kappa=1}^{k} |1+e^{-i(2\pi h\kappa-\pi)}|^2 |\sigma_{\pi h}(\pi h-\pi)|^2= 4^k\,h\,\prod_{\kappa=1}^{k} |\sin(\pi h\kappa)|^2.$$ This formula and formulas [as:x] and [def:F0] imply [formula:X0pk]. ◻

section_path: Monodromy matrices, monodromy equation and spectral results / Gaps in the spectrum of the Harper equation: proof of Theorem 5 / The lengths of gaps
text:
Finally, we rewrite [cond:gap:3] in terms of $E$. We denote the right hand side in [cond:gap:3] by $\Delta_k$. As $E=2\cos (2\pi p)$, we get $$|g_k|\ge 2(\cos\big(2\pi(p_k-\Delta_k)\big)-\cos\big(2\pi(p_k+\Delta_k)\big)= 4\sin(2\pi p_k)\sin (2\pi \Delta_k).$$ As $X_0(p_k)=O_H(\lambda^k )$, we get $|\Delta_k|=O_H(\lambda^k),$ and, by means of [as:pk], we obtain $$|g_k|\ge 8\pi\Delta_k \,\sin(2\pi p_k)(1+O_H(\lambda^{2k}))=8\pi\Delta_k \,\sin(\pi hk)(1+O_H(\lambda^{\beta})).$$ Substituting into this estimate instead of $\Delta_k$ the right hand side from [cond:gap:3] and using formula [formula:X0pk], we come to [eq:gk]. This completes the proof Theorem 5.0◻ We will use the following immediate corollary from the above proof:
**Corollary 4**. *The right hand side in [eq:gk] satisfies equals to $\lambda^ke^{O(1/h)}$.*
*Proof.* As $X_0(p_k)=O_H(\lambda^k )$, it suffices to compare [eq:gk] with [formula:X0pk]. ◻

section_path: Model equation
text:
# Model equation

Entire solutions to the equation $$\label{mu:eq}
\mu\,(z+h)+\mu\,(z-h)+e^{-2\pi i z}\mu(z)=2\cos(2\pi p)\,\mu(z),\quad
z\in {\mathbb C}.$$ were constructed in . Here, we briefly recall construction of these solutions, and get for them estimates uniform in $h$.

section_path: Model equation / Construction of solutions
text: ## Construction of solutions

section_path: Model equation / Construction of solutions / Integral representation
Model equation / Construction of solutions / Properties of the function $v$
Model equation / Construction of solutions / Integration path
text: ### Integration path We choose the integration path in [mu:form] so that it does not intersect $l _\pm$, comes from infinity from bottom to top along the line $e ^ {i \pi / 4} \, {\mathbb R}$ and goes to infinity upward along the line $e ^ {3i \pi / 4} \, {\mathbb R}$. This completes the construction of $\mu$.

section_path: Model equation / Construction of solutions / Notations
text:
### Notations

Fix $X>0$. We study $\mu$ in the strip $|x|\le X$ assuming that $p\in P$, $$%
P=\{p\in{\mathbb C}\,:\,0\le {\rm Re}\,p\le 1/2, \,|{\rm Im}\,p|\le h\}.$$

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the upper half-plane
text:
## Estimates in the upper half-plane Let $$% \xi_\pm(z)=e^{\pm\frac{\pi iz^2}{h}+ \frac{i\pi z}h+\pi iz}.$$ One has
**Proposition 4**. *Let us pick $X, Y>0$. Assume that $p\in P$. One has $$\label{mu:up} % \mu=\nu_+\,\xi_++\nu_-\,\xi_-,\qquad \nu_\pm=\mp e^{\mp\frac{i\pi}4}\,v_\pm\,F_\pm; %$$ and for $|x|\le X$ the functions $F_\pm$ satisfy the uniform in $x$ estimates: $$\label{mu:up:Delta} F_\pm=O(H)\ \text{ if } \ y\ge -Y, \qquad \text{and}\qquad F_\pm=1+o(1) \ \text{ as } \ y\to+\infty.$$*
*Proof.* In view of [v:down]– [v:up], as $q\to\pm \infty$ the behavior of the integrand in [mu:form] is described by the exponentials $$\label{exps} e^{\frac{2\pi ik z}h}\,e^{\mp\frac{i\pi (k-{\textstyle \frac12}-{\textstyle \frac h2} )^2}{h}}= \xi_\pm(z)\,e^{\mp\frac{\pi i(k-k_\pm(z))^2}{h}}, \quad\text{where}\quad k_\pm(z)=\pm z+{\textstyle \frac h2+\frac12}.$$ Let us consider the straight lines $$L_\pm(z)=k_\pm(z)+e^{\mp\pi i/4}{\mathbb R}.$$ The lines $L_\pm(z)$ are lines of steepest descent for the functions $k\mapsto|e^{\mp\frac{\pi i(k-k_\pm(z))^2}{h}}|$. They intersect one another at $k_*=y+ix+h/2+1/2$. Let us pick $d_0>0$. There is an $Y>0$ such that if $y>Y$, then for all $(h,p,x)\in (0,1)\times P\times [-X,X]$, the distance from $L_\pm$ to $l_\pm$ is greater than $d_0$.

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the upper half-plane
Model equation / Estimates in the upper half-plane
Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text:
## Estimates in the lower half-plane Set $$\label{a(p,h)} a(p)=e^{-\frac{i\pi}{12h}+\frac{i\pi}4-\frac{\pi ih}{12}} \ e^{\frac{\pi ip^2}{h}-\frac{ip\pi}h-\pi ip}\, \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)).$$ We note that $a$ is meromorphic in $p$, and its poles in $(-\infty,0]$ . One has
**Proposition 5**. *Pick positive $X$. Let $p\in P$. There is an $Y>0$ independent of $p$ and $h$ and such that, for $y\le -Y$ and $|x|\le X$, one has the following results $\bullet$  Fix $\alpha$, $\beta$ so that $0<\beta<\alpha<1$. Then, $$\label{mu:down:1} \mu(z)= e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}\left( a(p)+ % O_H\big(\,e^{-2\pi \beta |y|}\,\big)\right),\quad % {\rm if}\quad {\rm Re}\,p\ge \alpha h/2,\quad %$$ $\bullet$  Fix $\alpha$ and $\beta'$ so that $0<\alpha<1$ and $0<\beta'<1$. Then $$\label{mu:down:2} \begin{split} \mu(z)= a(p)\,e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}+a(-p)\,e^{-\frac{2\pi ip z}h}&+ % O_H\left(\,e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h-2\pi \beta'|y|}\,\right),\\ % &{\rm if}\quad 0\le {\rm Re}\,p\le \alpha h/2. % \end{split}$$*
*Proof.* Let us begin with justifying [mu:down:1]. Remind that $\mu$ has the integral representation [mu:form]. For $y<0$, the behavior of $\mu$ appears to be determined by the rightmost poles of $v$.

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text: *Proof.* Let us begin with justifying [mu:down:1]. Remind that $\mu$ has the integral representation [mu:form]. For $y<0$, the behavior of $\mu$ appears to be determined by the rightmost poles of $v$. The poles of $v$ are at the points listed in [v:poles]. As $p\in P$, they are inside the strip $|{\rm Im}\,k|\le h$. As ${\rm Re}\,p\ge \alpha h/2$,  $0<\alpha<1$, we see that, to the right of the line ${\rm Re}\, k={\rm Re}\, p-\alpha h$, the function $v$ has only one simple pole; it is situated at $k=p$. We deform $\gamma$, the integration contour in [mu:form], to a curve that has the same asymptotes as $\gamma$, but, instead of staying to the right of all the poles of $v$, it goes between the pole at $k=p$ and the other ones (they stay to the left of this curve). We keep for the new integration curve the old notation $\gamma$. One has $$\label{mu:res:1} \begin{split} &\mu= A+B, \\ % A= \frac{2\pi i}{\sqrt{ h}}\, {\rm res}\, _{k=p}\,I(k),\quad &B= \frac1{\sqrt{h}}\,\int_{\gamma}I(k)\,dk,\qquad I=e^{\frac{2\pi ikz}h}\, v\,(k). \end{split}$$ Using the representation [v:form], the information on the poles of the function $\sigma_{\pi h}(z)$ from section 8.1.2, and formula [sigma:res], we get $$% A=a(p)\,e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}$$ with $a(p)$ given by [a(p,h)].

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text: We deform $\gamma$, the integration contour in [mu:form], to a curve that has the same asymptotes as $\gamma$, but, instead of staying to the right of all the poles of $v$, it goes between the pole at $k=p$ and the other ones (they stay to the left of this curve). We keep for the new integration curve the old notation $\gamma$. One has $$\label{mu:res:1} \begin{split} &\mu= A+B, \\ % A= \frac{2\pi i}{\sqrt{ h}}\, {\rm res}\, _{k=p}\,I(k),\quad &B= \frac1{\sqrt{h}}\,\int_{\gamma}I(k)\,dk,\qquad I=e^{\frac{2\pi ikz}h}\, v\,(k). \end{split}$$ Using the representation [v:form], the information on the poles of the function $\sigma_{\pi h}(z)$ from section 8.1.2, and formula [sigma:res], we get $$% A=a(p)\,e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}$$ with $a(p)$ given by [a(p,h)]. Now, to complete the proof of the proposition, we need only to estimate the term $B$ in [mu:res:1]. Let $\gamma_+$ ($\gamma_-$) be the part of $\gamma$ located above (resp., below) the line ${\rm Im}\,k={\rm Im}\,p$. First, we choose $\gamma_\pm$, and then, we prove that $$\label{gamma1gamma2} \left|\int_{\gamma_\pm}I(k)\,dk\right|\le H\,\left|e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}\right|\, e^{-2\pi \beta |y|}.$$ We begin with estimating the integral along $\gamma_-$. We remind that the exponential $e^{\frac{\pi i(k-k_-(z))^2}{h}}$ governs the behavior of $I(k)$, the integrand in [mu:form], as ${\rm Im}\,k\to-\infty$, see the beginning of the proof of Proposition 4. We assume that $y<-Y$ with a positive $Y$. Therefore, ${\rm Im}\,k_-(z)>Y$. For $\xi\in{\mathbb C}$, we denote by $H_i(\xi)$ the smooth curve described by an equation of the form ${\rm Im}\,(k-k_-(z))^2=c$,  $c\in{\mathbb R}$, and containing $\xi$. If $c=0$ this curve is one of the straight lines $k_-(z)+{\mathbb R}$ and $k_-(z)+i{\mathbb R}$, otherwise it is a hyperbola located in one of the sectors bounded by these lines. Its asymptotes are two half lines of these straight lines. Let $H_r(\xi)$ be the smooth curve described by an equation of the form ${\rm Re}\,(k-k_-(z))^2=c$,  $c\in{\mathbb R}$, and containing $\xi$. If $c=0$ this curve is one of the straight lines $k_-(z)+e^{\pm \frac{i\pi}4}{\mathbb R}$, otherwise it is a hyperbola located in one of the sectors bounded by these lines, and they are its asymptotes.

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text: For $\xi\in{\mathbb C}$, we denote by $H_i(\xi)$ the smooth curve described by an equation of the form ${\rm Im}\,(k-k_-(z))^2=c$,  $c\in{\mathbb R}$, and containing $\xi$. If $c=0$ this curve is one of the straight lines $k_-(z)+{\mathbb R}$ and $k_-(z)+i{\mathbb R}$, otherwise it is a hyperbola located in one of the sectors bounded by these lines. Its asymptotes are two half lines of these straight lines. Let $H_r(\xi)$ be the smooth curve described by an equation of the form ${\rm Re}\,(k-k_-(z))^2=c$,  $c\in{\mathbb R}$, and containing $\xi$. If $c=0$ this curve is one of the straight lines $k_-(z)+e^{\pm \frac{i\pi}4}{\mathbb R}$, otherwise it is a hyperbola located in one of the sectors bounded by these lines, and they are its asymptotes. Set $k_1=p-\beta h$. As $0<\beta<\alpha<1$, the point $k_1$ is to the right of the line ${\rm Re}\,k=p-\alpha h$ and to the left of $p$. As $p\in P$, one has $|{\rm Im}\,k_1|\le h<1$. Let $Y$ be sufficiently large, and $y<-Y$. Then the hyperbola $H_i(k_1)$ stays in the half plane ${\rm Im}\,k< {\rm Im}\,k_-(z)$ and intersects the line ${\rm Im}\, k=-2$ at a point $k_2$.We denote by $\gamma_1$ its segment of $H_i(k_1)$ between $k_1$ and $k_2$. Furthermore, if $Y$ is sufficiently large, $H_r(k_2)$ is a hyperbola located below $k_-(z)$. We denote by $\gamma_2$ its segment between $k_2$ and $\infty$ along which ${\rm Re}\,k\to -\infty$ as $k\to\infty$. The curve $\gamma_-$ is the union of $\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_2$, see Fig. [fig:1].

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text: Let $Y$ be sufficiently large, and $y<-Y$. Then the hyperbola $H_i(k_1)$ stays in the half plane ${\rm Im}\,k< {\rm Im}\,k_-(z)$ and intersects the line ${\rm Im}\, k=-2$ at a point $k_2$.We denote by $\gamma_1$ its segment of $H_i(k_1)$ between $k_1$ and $k_2$. Furthermore, if $Y$ is sufficiently large, $H_r(k_2)$ is a hyperbola located below $k_-(z)$. We denote by $\gamma_2$ its segment between $k_2$ and $\infty$ along which ${\rm Re}\,k\to -\infty$ as $k\to\infty$. The curve $\gamma_-$ is the union of $\gamma_1$ and $\gamma_2$, see Fig. [fig:1]. If $Y$ is sufficiently big, then (1) the curve $\gamma_-$ does stays between $p$ and all the other poles of $v$; (2) its segment $\gamma_2$ is located below the poles of the integrand at a distance greater than $1$. Let us estimate $\int_{\gamma_1}I(p)\,dp$. We note that, by the definition of $H_i$ and by [exps], the expression ${\rm Im}\,\left(2k z+k^2-k-kh\right)$ is constant on $H_i(k_1)$. By [v:form] we get $$\begin{gathered} \label{int-term:1} \left|\frac1{\sqrt{h}} \int_{\gamma_1}e^{\frac{2\pi izk}h}v(k)dk\right| \le \frac{C\left|e^{-\frac{C(H_i)}{h}}\right|}{\sqrt{h}}\times\\ \times\int_{\gamma_1} |\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k+p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12})) \sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12}))dk| \end{gathered}$$ where $$C(H_i)=\pi \left. {\rm Im}\,\left(2kz+k^2-k-kh\right) \right|_{H_i(k_1)},\quad$$ Computing $C(H_i)$ at the point $k_1$, we get $$\label{C(H)} \left|e^{-\frac{C(H_i)}{h}}\right|\le C\,\left|e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}\right|\, e^{-2\pi \beta |y|}.$$ Let us estimate the integrand in the right hand side of [int-term:1]. Using [eq:sigma], we get $$\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p-{\textstyle\frac h2-\frac12}))= \frac{\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p+{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12}))}{1-e^{-2\pi i(k-p)}}.$$ For $k\in\gamma_1$, one has $$% \begin{split} {\rm Re}\,(k+p-h/2 -1/2)&\ge -1/2-h/2+2{\rm Re}\,p - \beta h - C(Y) |{\rm Im}\,(k-p)|\\ &\ge -1/2-h/2+(\alpha - \beta) h - C(Y) |{\rm Im}\,(k-p)|, \\ % {\rm Re}\,(k-p+h/2 -1/2)&\ge -1/2-h/2+(1-\beta) h-C(Y) |{\rm Im}\,(k-p)|. % \end{split}$$ where $C(Y)>0$ tends to zero as $Y\to\infty$. These observations and Corollaries 9– 10 imply that, for sufficiently large $Y$ and $k\in\gamma_1$, $$|\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k+p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12}))\, \sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p-{\textstyle\frac h2-\frac12}))|\le H.$$ This estimate and [C(H)] imply estimate [gamma1gamma2] with $\gamma_1$ instead of $\gamma_\pm$.

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text: If $Y$ is sufficiently big, then (1) the curve $\gamma_-$ does stays between $p$ and all the other poles of $v$; (2) its segment $\gamma_2$ is located below the poles of the integrand at a distance greater than $1$. Let us estimate $\int_{\gamma_1}I(p)\,dp$. We note that, by the definition of $H_i$ and by [exps], the expression ${\rm Im}\,\left(2k z+k^2-k-kh\right)$ is constant on $H_i(k_1)$. By [v:form] we get $$\begin{gathered} \label{int-term:1} \left|\frac1{\sqrt{h}} \int_{\gamma_1}e^{\frac{2\pi izk}h}v(k)dk\right| \le \frac{C\left|e^{-\frac{C(H_i)}{h}}\right|}{\sqrt{h}}\times\\ \times\int_{\gamma_1} |\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k+p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12})) \sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12}))dk| \end{gathered}$$ where $$C(H_i)=\pi \left. {\rm Im}\,\left(2kz+k^2-k-kh\right) \right|_{H_i(k_1)},\quad$$ Computing $C(H_i)$ at the point $k_1$, we get $$\label{C(H)} \left|e^{-\frac{C(H_i)}{h}}\right|\le C\,\left|e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}\right|\, e^{-2\pi \beta |y|}.$$ Let us estimate the integrand in the right hand side of [int-term:1]. Using [eq:sigma], we get $$\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p-{\textstyle\frac h2-\frac12}))= \frac{\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p+{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12}))}{1-e^{-2\pi i(k-p)}}.$$ For $k\in\gamma_1$, one has $$% \begin{split} {\rm Re}\,(k+p-h/2 -1/2)&\ge -1/2-h/2+2{\rm Re}\,p - \beta h - C(Y) |{\rm Im}\,(k-p)|\\ &\ge -1/2-h/2+(\alpha - \beta) h - C(Y) |{\rm Im}\,(k-p)|, \\ % {\rm Re}\,(k-p+h/2 -1/2)&\ge -1/2-h/2+(1-\beta) h-C(Y) |{\rm Im}\,(k-p)|. % \end{split}$$ where $C(Y)>0$ tends to zero as $Y\to\infty$. These observations and Corollaries 9– 10 imply that, for sufficiently large $Y$ and $k\in\gamma_1$, $$|\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k+p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12}))\, \sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k-p-{\textstyle\frac h2-\frac12}))|\le H.$$ This estimate and [C(H)] imply estimate [gamma1gamma2] with $\gamma_1$ instead of $\gamma_\pm$. Consider the integral $\int_{\gamma_2}I(k)\,dk$. As $\gamma_2$ stays below the poles of $I$, at a distance greater than $1$, by means of Corollary 9, one immediately obtains $$|\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k+p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12} ))\, \sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi (k-p-{\textstyle\frac h2-\frac12} ))|\le H,\quad k\in\gamma_2,$$ and $$\left|\int_{\gamma_2} I\,dk\right|\le H\, \left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h\,\left.(2kz+k^2- k-kh)\right|_{k=k_2}} \right|\,\int_{\gamma_2}\left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h ((k-k_-(z))^2-(k_2-k_-(z))^2)} \,dk \right|.$$ Clearly, $$\left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h \left.(2kz+k^2-k-kh)\right|_{k=k_2}}\right|=e^{-\frac{C(H_i)}h}\le C\,\left|e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}\right| e^{-2\pi\beta |y|}.$$ We remind that curve $\gamma_2\subset H_r(k_2)$ goes to infinity approaching the asymptote $e^{i\pi/4}(-\infty,0]$. Integrating by parts, we get $$\int_{\gamma_2} \left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h ((k-k_-(z))^2-(k_2-k_-(z))^2)} \,dk\right|\le Ch/|k_2-k_-|.$$ These estimates imply that $\int_{\gamma_2} I\,dk$ satisfies an estimate of the form [gamma1gamma2]. This implies [gamma1gamma2] with $\gamma_-$.

section_path: Model equation / Estimates in the lower half-plane
text: Consider the integral $\int_{\gamma_2}I(k)\,dk$. As $\gamma_2$ stays below the poles of $I$, at a distance greater than $1$, by means of Corollary 9, one immediately obtains $$|\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(k+p-{\textstyle \frac h2-\frac12} ))\, \sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi (k-p-{\textstyle\frac h2-\frac12} ))|\le H,\quad k\in\gamma_2,$$ and $$\left|\int_{\gamma_2} I\,dk\right|\le H\, \left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h\,\left.(2kz+k^2- k-kh)\right|_{k=k_2}} \right|\,\int_{\gamma_2}\left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h ((k-k_-(z))^2-(k_2-k_-(z))^2)} \,dk \right|.$$ Clearly, $$\left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h \left.(2kz+k^2-k-kh)\right|_{k=k_2}}\right|=e^{-\frac{C(H_i)}h}\le C\,\left|e^{\frac{2\pi ip z}h}\right| e^{-2\pi\beta |y|}.$$ We remind that curve $\gamma_2\subset H_r(k_2)$ goes to infinity approaching the asymptote $e^{i\pi/4}(-\infty,0]$. Integrating by parts, we get $$\int_{\gamma_2} \left|e^{\frac{\pi i}h ((k-k_-(z))^2-(k_2-k_-(z))^2)} \,dk\right|\le Ch/|k_2-k_-|.$$ These estimates imply that $\int_{\gamma_2} I\,dk$ satisfies an estimate of the form [gamma1gamma2]. This implies [gamma1gamma2] with $\gamma_-$. The estimates of the integral along $\gamma_+$, the part of $\gamma$ above the line ${\rm Im}\,k={\rm Im}\,p$ are similar. We omit the details and mention only that now the role of $e^{i\frac{(k-k_-(z))^2}h}$ is played by the exponential $e^{-i\frac{(k-k_+(z))^2}h}$. The obtained estimates and the formula for $A$ imply [mu:down:1]. This completes the proof of [mu:down:1]. Representation [mu:down:2] is obtained similarly. ◻

section_path: Model equation / Rough estimates
text:
## Rough estimates We shall need
**Lemma 7**. *Pick $X>0$. Let $p\in P$ and $|x|\le X$. One has $$\label{mu-est} |\mu(z)|,\; |\mu'(z)|\le H w(x,y),\quad w(x,y)=(1+|y|)\begin{cases} e^{\frac{2\pi(|x|-1/2)y}h-\pi y}, & y\ge 0,\\ e^{\frac{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p |y|}h}, & y\le 0. \end{cases}$$*
When proving this lemma we use
**Lemma 8**. *Pick $\alpha\in (0,1)$. For $p\in P$ one has $$\label{est:a0} |a(p)|\le H\quad\text{if}\quad |p|\ge \alpha h/2,$$ $$\label{est:a_0} % |a(p)+a(-p)|\le H,\quad |p a(p)|\le H\quad\text{if}\quad |p|\le \alpha h/2.$$*
*Proof.* Let $|p|\ge \alpha h/2$ and $p\in P$. Corollaries 9 and 10 imply that $|\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi))|\le H$. This and [a(p,h)] lead to [est:a0].

section_path: Model equation / Rough estimates
text: *Proof.* Let $|p|\ge \alpha h/2$ and $p\in P$. Corollaries 9 and 10 imply that $|\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi))|\le H$. This and [a(p,h)] lead to [est:a0]. Assume that $|p|\le\alpha h/2$ ($p$ is not necessarily in $P$). In view of [a(p,h)], it suffices to check that $$% |\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)+ \sigma_{\pi h}(-4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)|\le \frac{C}h,\quad % |p \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)|\le C.$$ Both the functions $p\mapsto \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)+ \sigma_{\pi h}(-4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)$ and $p\mapsto p\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)$ are analytic in $p$ in the $\frac{\alpha h}2$-neighborhood of zero (see section 8.1.2). By Theorem 12 $\sigma_{\pi h}(2\pi(2p-{\textstyle\frac{h}2-\frac12}))$ is bounded by $C/h$ at the boundary of this neighborhood. This and the maximum principle imply the needed estimates. ◻ Now we can check Lemma 7.

section_path: Model equation / Rough estimates
text: *Proof.* Let $p\in P$. Pick $Y$ sufficiently large. For $y\ge - Y$, the estimate for $\mu$ follows directly from Proposition 4. For $|y|\le Y$, the estimate for $\mu'$ follows from the estimate for $\mu$ and the Cauchy estimates for the derivatives of analytic functions (as $X$ and $Y$ were chosen rather arbitrarily). Let $y\ge Y$ and $|x|\le X$. The first estimate in [mu-est] implies that, in the $(h/y)$-neighborhood of $z$, $\mu$ is bounded by $H w(x,y)$ (we again use the fact that $X$ and $Y$ were chosen rather arbitrarily). This and the Cauchy estimates for the derivatives of analytic functions lead then to the estimate $|\mu'(z)|\le yH w(x,y)$. This completes the proof of [mu-est] for $y\ge -Y$.

section_path: Model equation / Rough estimates
Model equation / One more solution to the model equation
text:
## One more solution to the model equation Let $$\label{tildeMu} \tilde\mu\,(z,p)=e^{-i\pi z/h}\,\mu\,(z+1/2,1/2-p),$$ were we indicate the dependence of $\mu$ on $p$ explicitly. Together with $\mu$,  $\tilde \mu$ is a solution to [mu:eq]. It is entire in $z$ and $p$. We use it to construct entire solutions to the Harper equation. Here, we compute the Wronskian $\{\mu,\,\tilde \mu\}= \mu(z+h) \tilde \mu(z)-\mu(z)\tilde \mu(z+h)$.
**Lemma 9**. *For all $p\in{\mathbb C}$, $$\label{wronskian:formula} \{\mu,\,\tilde \mu\}= ie^{-\frac{2\pi i p^2}h-\frac{i\pi}{12h}-\frac{\pi ih}3}.$$*

heading.title: One more solution to the model equation

section_path: Model equation / One more solution to the model equation
text: *Proof.* Pick $X>0$ and $0<\alpha<\frac12$. Assume that $\alpha h/2\le p\le1/2-\alpha h/2$. Then, by means of [tildeMu], [mu:down:1] and [est:a0], we check that, uniformly in $x\in [-X,X]$, as $y\to-\infty$ the Wronskian $\{\mu,\,\tilde \mu\}$ tends to $$\label{eq:2:w} 2i e^{\frac{i\pi}{2h}-\frac{i\pi p}h}\,a(1/2-p)a(p)\sin(2\pi p) .$$ By means of [mu-est], we check that, as $y\to+\infty$, uniformly in $x\in[-h,0]$, $$|\{\mu(z),\,\tilde \mu(z)\}|\le H |y| \left( e^{\frac{2\pi y}h (x-\frac12+|x+1/2|)}+1\right)\le H |y|.$$ The Wronskian being entire (as $\mu$ and $\tilde \mu$) and $h$-periodic in $z$ (as the Wronskian of any two solutions to a one-dimensional difference Schrödinger equation, see section 3.1.3), we conclude that it is independent of $z$ and equals the expression in [eq:2:w]. As the Wronskian is entire in $p$, this statement is valid for all $p$. Finally, using the definition of $a$, equation [eq:sigma] and formula [sigma:sym], we check that $$\label{wr-relation} 2i \,a(1/2-p)a(p)\sin(2\pi p)= ie^{-\frac{2\pi i p^2}h+\frac{i\pi p}h-\frac{7i\pi}{12h}-\frac{\pi ih}3}.$$ This leads to the statement of the lemma. ◻

heading.title: One more solution to the model equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation
text: # Analytic solution to Harper equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Preliminaries
text:
## Preliminaries For $Y\in{\mathbb R}$, we set ${\mathbb C}_+(Y)=\{y> Y\}$. Here, we pick $Y>0$ and for sufficiently small $\lambda>0$ construct a solution to [eq:harper] analytic in ${\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$. Below, we represent the spectral parameter $E$ in the form $E=2\cos (2\pi p)$ and consider solutions to [eq:harper] as functions of the parameter $p$. As $\lambda$ is small, then, when constructing solutions to [eq:harper] in ${\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$, it is natural to rewrite this equation in the form $$\label{pert-model} \psi\,(z+h)+\psi\,(z-h)+\lambda\,e^{-2\pi iz}\psi\,(z)-2\cos(2\pi p)\,\psi(z)= -\lambda\,e^{2\pi iz}\,\psi(z),$$ so that the term in the right hand side could be considered as a perturbation. Let $\xi=\frac1{2\pi}\ln\lambda$. Then $\mu(z+i\xi)$ is a solution to the unperturbed equation $$\label{un-pert-eq} \psi\,(z+h)+\psi\,(z-h)+\lambda\,e^{-2\pi iz}\psi\,(z)-2\cos(2\pi p)\,\psi(z)=0.$$ We construct $\psi$, an analytic solution to equation [pert-model] close to $\mu(z+i\xi)$. We prove
**Theorem 7**. *Pick positive $Y$. There exists $C$ such that if  $\lambda\le e^{-\frac Ch}$,  then:* *$\bullet$   There is $\psi_0$, a solution to [eq:harper] analytic in $(z,p)\in {\mathbb C}_+(-Y)\times P$;*

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Preliminaries
text: *$\bullet$   There is $\psi_0$, a solution to [eq:harper] analytic in $(z,p)\in {\mathbb C}_+(-Y)\times P$;* *$\bullet$   Pick positive $X$. As $y\to+\infty$, uniformly in $x\in[-X,X]$ $$\label{psi-0:up} % \psi_0(z)=e^{\frac{i\pi}4}\,\xi_-(z+i\xi)\,v_-\,(1+\varkappa_0 +o(1)) -e^{-\frac{i\pi}4}\,\xi_+(z+i\xi)\,v_+\,(1+o(1)), %$$ where $\varkappa_0$ is a constant satisfying the estimate $$\textstyle |\varkappa_0|\le H\lambda^{1+\nu(p)}(1+|\xi|)^3,\quad \nu(p)=\min\left\{1,\frac{1-2{\rm Re}\,p}h\right\}.$$* *$\bullet$   Fix $X>0$. For $|x|\le X$ and $y\le Y/2$, one has $$\label{psi-0:down} |\psi_0(z)-\mu(z+i\xi)|\le H\lambda (1+|\xi|)^3\,e^{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p|\xi|/h}.$$* The rest of the section is devoted to the proof of Theorem 7.

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Preliminaries
Analytic solution to Harper equation / Integral equation
text:
## Integral equation

Here, we prove the existence of a solution (continuous in $z$ and analytic in $p$) to the integral equation. Below, $$%
q(y)=(1+|y|)\begin{cases}
e^{-\frac{\pi y}h-\pi y}, &y\ge 0,\\
e^{\frac{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p |y|}h},&y\le 0,
\end{cases}
\quad
\tilde q(y)=(1+|y|)\begin{cases}
e^{+\frac{\pi y}h-\pi y}, & y\ge 0,\\
e^{-\frac{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p |y|}h},& y\le 0.
\end{cases}$$

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Integral equation / Estimates of $\mu$ and $\tilde \mu$
text:
### Estimates of $\mu$ and $\tilde \mu$ To estimate the norm of the integral operator, we use
**Corollary 5**. *On the curve $\gamma$, the functions $\mu$ and $\tilde \mu$ satisfy the estimates $$\label{mu-est:rough} |\mu(z)|,\,|\mu'(z)| \le H q(y),\qquad % |\tilde \mu(z)|,\,|\tilde \mu'(z)|\le H \tilde q(y),$$*
This Corollary follows directly from Lemma 7.

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Integral equation / A solution to the integral equation
text:
### A solution to the integral equation One has
**Proposition 6**. *Fix positive $\alpha<1$. There is a positive constant $C$ such that if $\lambda\le e^{-\frac{C}h}$, then the integral equation [int-eq] has a solution $\psi_0$ continuous in $z\in\gamma$, analytic in $p\in P$ and satisfying the estimate $$\label{est:psi-a:1} \left|\psi_0(z)-\mu(z+i\xi)\right|\le \lambda^\alpha H q(y+\xi),\quad z\in\gamma.$$*
*Proof.* Let $C(\gamma,q)$ be the space of functions defined and continuous on $\gamma$ and having the finite norm $\|f\|=\sup_{z\in \gamma} |q^{-1}(y+\xi)\,f(z)|$. The proof is based on
**Lemma 10**. *For $z,\,z'\in \gamma$, one has $$\label{kernel-estimate} |q^{-1}(y+\xi)\,\kappa\,(z,\,z')\,q(y'+\xi)|\le \lambda\,H\, e^{-2\pi y'}(1+\xi^2).$$*

heading.title: A solution to the integral equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Integral equation / A solution to the integral equation
text: First, we prove the proposition, and then, we check estimate [kernel-estimate]. This estimate implies that the norm of $K$ as an operator acting in $C(\gamma, q)$ is bounded by $\lambda\,H\,(1+\xi^{2})$. By Corollary 5, $\mu(.+\xi)\in C(\gamma,q)$. So, there is a positive constant $C$ such that, if $\lambda(1+\xi^{2})\, [int-eq] from $C(\gamma,q)$. The estimate of the norm of the integral operator implies that $$\left|\psi_0(z)-\mu(z)\right|\le \lambda(1+\xi^{2})H q(y+\xi),\quad z\in\gamma.$$ This implies [est:psi-a:1] for any fixed positive $\alpha<1$. The analyticity of $\psi_0$ in $p$ follows from one of $\mu$ and the uniformity of the estimates. The proof is complete.0◻ Let us prove Lemma 10. Below, $z,z'\in \gamma$. We note that by [wronskian:formula], for $p\in P$ one has $C^{-1}\le \{\mu(z),\tilde\mu(z)\}\le C$.

heading.title: A solution to the integral equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Integral equation / A solution to the integral equation
text: Let us prove Lemma 10. Below, $z,z'\in \gamma$. We note that by [wronskian:formula], for $p\in P$ one has $C^{-1}\le \{\mu(z),\tilde\mu(z)\}\le C$. First, we consider the case where $|y-y'|\ge h$. In view of Corollary 5, we get $$\begin{gathered} |q^{-1}(y+\xi)\,\kappa\,(z,\,z')\,q(y'+\xi)|\le \lambda H e^{-2\pi y'}(E_1+E_2),\\ E_1=|\Theta(z,z')|\,\tilde q(y'+\xi)\,q(y'+\xi),\qquad E_2=|\Theta(z,z')|\,\frac{\tilde q(y+\xi)}{q(y+\xi)}\,q^2(y'+\xi). \end{gathered}$$ To justify [kernel-estimate], it suffices to check that $E_{1,2}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2$. Note that $$\label{est:theta} |\Theta(z,z')|\le C\,\begin{cases} e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}&\text{ if }y-y'\ge h,\\ 1 & \text{ if } y'-y\ge h.\end{cases}$$ Clearly, $E_1\le C\,\tilde q(y'+\xi) q(y'+\xi)$. For $y'\ge -Y$, we have $$\label{kernel-estimate:2a} \begin{split} \tilde q(y'+\xi) q(y'+\xi)&\le (1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi(y'+\xi)}\le C,\quad \text{if}\quad y'+\xi\ge0,\\ \tilde q(y'+\xi) q(y'+\xi)&\le (1+|y'+\xi|)^2\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2 \quad \text{otherwise}. \end{split}$$ This implies that $E_{1}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2$. To estimate $E_2$, we have to consider four cases. If $y+\xi,\,y'+\xi\ge 0$, we have $$E_2\le |\Theta(z,z')|\,(1+|y'+\xi|)^2\,e^{\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h-2\pi (y'+\xi)} \le C\, |\Theta(z,z')|\,e^{\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}\le C.$$ If $y+\xi\ge 0\ge y'+\xi$, then $$\begin{split} E_2\le(1+|y'+\xi|)^2\, &|\Theta(z,z')|\, e^{\frac{2\pi(y+\xi)}h-\frac{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p(y'+\xi)}h}\\ &\le C\,(1+\xi^2)\,e^{\frac{2\pi (1-2{\rm Re}\,p)(y'+\xi)}h}\le C\,(1+\xi^2). \end{split}$$ If $y'+\xi\ge 0\ge y+\xi$, then $$\begin{split} E_2\le (1+|&y'+\xi|)^2\,|\Theta(z,z')|\, e^{\frac{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p(y+\xi)}h-\frac{2\pi(y'+\xi)}h-2\pi (y'+\xi)}\\ &\le C\,|\Theta(z,z')|\,e^{\frac{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p(y+\xi)}h-\frac{2\pi(y'+\xi)}h} \le C\,|\Theta(z,z')|\le C. \end{split}$$ Finally, if $y+\xi,\,y'+\xi\le 0$, we get $$E_2\le (1+|y'+\xi|)^2\,|\Theta(z,z')|\,e^{\frac{4\pi {\rm Re}\,p(y-y')}h}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2.$$ These estimates imply that $E_{2}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2$. This completes the proof in the case where $|y-y'|\ge h$. Let us consider the case where $|y-y'|\le h$. Let $\eta={\rm Im}\,\zeta$. Using [mu-est] we get $$\begin{split} |\Theta(z,z') \,(\mu(z+i&\xi)\,\tilde \mu\,(z'+i\xi)- \mu\,(z'+i\xi)\,\tilde \mu\,(z+i\xi)\,)|\\ &\le Ch\,\max_{\zeta\in\gamma,\, |y-\eta|\le h}\left| \mu(z+i\xi)\,\tilde \mu'(\zeta+i\xi)- \mu'(\zeta+i\xi)\,\tilde \mu\,(z+i\xi)\right|\\ &\le H \left(q(y+\xi)\max_{|y-\eta|\le h}\tilde q(\eta+\xi)+ \tilde q(y+\xi)\max_{|y-\eta|\le h}q(\eta+\xi)\right)\\ &\le Hq(y+\xi)\tilde q(y+\xi), \end{split}$$ and, using [kernel-estimate:2a], we again come to [kernel-estimate]. This completes the proof. ◻

heading.title: A solution to the integral equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Integral equation / A solution to the integral equation
text:
First, we consider the case where $|y-y'|\ge h$. In view of Corollary 5, we get $$\begin{gathered} |q^{-1}(y+\xi)\,\kappa\,(z,\,z')\,q(y'+\xi)|\le \lambda H e^{-2\pi y'}(E_1+E_2),\\ E_1=|\Theta(z,z')|\,\tilde q(y'+\xi)\,q(y'+\xi),\qquad E_2=|\Theta(z,z')|\,\frac{\tilde q(y+\xi)}{q(y+\xi)}\,q^2(y'+\xi). \end{gathered}$$ To justify [kernel-estimate], it suffices to check that $E_{1,2}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2$. Note that $$\label{est:theta} |\Theta(z,z')|\le C\,\begin{cases} e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}&\text{ if }y-y'\ge h,\\ 1 & \text{ if } y'-y\ge h.\end{cases}$$ Clearly, $E_1\le C\,\tilde q(y'+\xi) q(y'+\xi)$. For $y'\ge -Y$, we have $$\label{kernel-estimate:2a} \begin{split} \tilde q(y'+\xi) q(y'+\xi)&\le (1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi(y'+\xi)}\le C,\quad \text{if}\quad y'+\xi\ge0,\\ \tilde q(y'+\xi) q(y'+\xi)&\le (1+|y'+\xi|)^2\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2 \quad \text{otherwise}. \end{split}$$ This implies that $E_{1}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2$. To estimate $E_2$, we have to consider four cases. If $y+\xi,\,y'+\xi\ge 0$, we have $$E_2\le |\Theta(z,z')|\,(1+|y'+\xi|)^2\,e^{\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h-2\pi (y'+\xi)} \le C\, |\Theta(z,z')|\,e^{\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}\le C.$$ If $y+\xi\ge 0\ge y'+\xi$, then $$\begin{split} E_2\le(1+|y'+\xi|)^2\, &|\Theta(z,z')|\, e^{\frac{2\pi(y+\xi)}h-\frac{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p(y'+\xi)}h}\\ &\le C\,(1+\xi^2)\,e^{\frac{2\pi (1-2{\rm Re}\,p)(y'+\xi)}h}\le C\,(1+\xi^2). \end{split}$$ If $y'+\xi\ge 0\ge y+\xi$, then $$\begin{split} E_2\le (1+|&y'+\xi|)^2\,|\Theta(z,z')|\, e^{\frac{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p(y+\xi)}h-\frac{2\pi(y'+\xi)}h-2\pi (y'+\xi)}\\ &\le C\,|\Theta(z,z')|\,e^{\frac{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p(y+\xi)}h-\frac{2\pi(y'+\xi)}h} \le C\,|\Theta(z,z')|\le C. \end{split}$$ Finally, if $y+\xi,\,y'+\xi\le 0$, we get $$E_2\le (1+|y'+\xi|)^2\,|\Theta(z,z')|\,e^{\frac{4\pi {\rm Re}\,p(y-y')}h}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2.$$ These estimates imply that $E_{2}\le C\,(1+|\xi|)^2$. This completes the proof in the case where $|y-y'|\ge h$. Let us consider the case where $|y-y'|\le h$. Let $\eta={\rm Im}\,\zeta$. Using [mu-est] we get $$\begin{split} |\Theta(z,z') \,(\mu(z+i&\xi)\,\tilde \mu\,(z'+i\xi)- \mu\,(z'+i\xi)\,\tilde \mu\,(z+i\xi)\,)|\\ &\le Ch\,\max_{\zeta\in\gamma,\, |y-\eta|\le h}\left| \mu(z+i\xi)\,\tilde \mu'(\zeta+i\xi)- \mu'(\zeta+i\xi)\,\tilde \mu\,(z+i\xi)\right|\\ &\le H \left(q(y+\xi)\max_{|y-\eta|\le h}\tilde q(\eta+\xi)+ \tilde q(y+\xi)\max_{|y-\eta|\le h}q(\eta+\xi)\right)\\ &\le Hq(y+\xi)\tilde q(y+\xi), \end{split}$$ and, using [kernel-estimate:2a], we again come to [kernel-estimate]. This completes the proof. ◻ Note that Corollary 5 and Proposition 6 imply
**Corollary 6**. *In the case of Proposition 6, there is $C$ such that, for $\lambda\le e^{-\frac{C}h}$, $$\label{est:psi-a:2} |\psi_0(z)|\le H q(y+\xi),\quad z\in\gamma.$$*

heading.title: A solution to the integral equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Analytic continuation of the solution to the integral equation
text:
## Analytic continuation of the solution to the integral equation Here, we prove the first point of Theorem 7. One has
**Lemma 11**. *The solution $\psi_0$ can be analytically continued in ${\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$.*
Similar statements were checked in  and , we outline the proof only for the convenience of the reader.
*Proof.* For $z'\in \gamma$, the kernel $\kappa\,(z,\,z')$ is analytic in $z\in S_h=\{|{\rm Re}\,z|-Y\}$, and the function $K\psi_0$ can be analytically continued in $S_h$;  $\psi_0$, being a solution to [int-eq], can be also analytically continued in $S_h$. Having proved that $\psi_0$ is analytic in $S_h$, one can deform the integration contour in the formula for $K\psi_0$ inside $S_h$, and check that, in fact, $\psi_0$ can be analytically continued in $S_{2h}=\{|{\rm Re}\,z|<2h,y>-Y\}$. Continuing in this way, one comes to the statement of the Lemma. ◻
Below, we denote by $\psi_0$ also the analytic continuation of the old $\psi_0$.

heading.title: Analytic continuation of the solution to the integral equation

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Analytic continuation of the solution to the integral equation / Function $\psi_0$ and the difference equation
text:
### Function $\psi_0$ and the difference equation To check that $\psi_0$ satisfies [pert-model], we again borrow an argument from  and . We call a curve in ${\mathbb C}$ vertical if along it $x$ is a smooth function of $y$. For $z\in {\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$ we denote by $\gamma(z)$ a vertical curve that begins at $-iY$, goes upward to $z$, then comes back to the imaginary axis and goes along it to $+i\infty$. One can compute $K\psi_0(z)$ by the formula in [int-eq] with the integration path $\gamma$ replaced with $\gamma(z)$. Set $({\mathcal H}_0\,f)\,(z)=f\,(z+h)+f\,(z-h)+\lambda\,e^{-2\pi i z}f(z)- 2\cos(2\pi p)\,f(z)$. Then, ${\mathcal H}_0\,\psi_0=-{\mathcal H}_0\,K\psi_0$. Using [int-eq] with $\gamma$ replaced with $\gamma(z)$,  $z\in{\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$, we get $$({\mathcal H}_0\,K\, \psi_0)\,(z)= 2\pi i\;{\rm res}\, _{z'=z}\,\kappa\,(z+h,\,z')\,\psi_0(z')= \lambda\,e^{2\pi iz}\,\psi_0(z).$$ Thus, we come to
**Lemma 12**. *The solution $\psi_0$ satisfies equation [eq:harper] in ${\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$.*
The last two lemmas imply the first point of the Theorem 7.

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the upper half-plane
Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the upper half-plane
text: *Proof.* Let us estimate $I(\tilde\mu)$. We assume that $y+\xi>0$. Using [est:theta],  [mu-est:rough] and [est:psi-a:2], we get $$\begin{gathered} |I(\tilde \mu)(z)|\le H\left( \int_{y}^\infty (1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi (y'+\xi)}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'\right.\\ \hspace{3cm}+\int_{-\xi}^y e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}(1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi (y'+\xi)}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'\\ \left.+\int_{-Y}^{-\xi} e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}(1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi y'}dy'\right). \end{gathered}$$ The expression in the brackets is bounded by $$\int_{y}^\infty e^{-2\pi y'}dy'+ \int_{-\xi}^y e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'+ (1+|Y-\xi|^2)\int_{-Y}^{-\xi} e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'.$$ As $h<1$, this implies the first estimate from [psi-0:up:I]. Let us turn to $I(\mu)$. Arguing as when estimating $I(\tilde \mu)$, we check that $$\begin{gathered} \label{I(tilde-mu):up} % \left|\int_{\gamma,\,\,y'>y+h} \Theta\,(z,\,z')\,\mu\,( z'+i\xi)\,e^{2\pi iz'}\,\psi_0(z') dz'\right|\le\\ \le H\int_{y+h}^\infty (1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-\frac{2\pi (y'+\xi)}h-2\pi (y'+\xi)}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'=o(e^{-\frac{2\pi y}h}) % \end{gathered}$$ uniformly in $x$ as $y\to+\infty$. Then, using the estimate $$\left|\Theta(z,z')-2ie^{-\frac{2\pi i(z'-z)}h}\right|\le C e^{-\frac{4\pi (y-y')}h},\quad y-y'\ge h,$$ and again arguing as before, we prove that as $y\to\infty$, uniformly in $x$ $$\label{I(tilde-mu):down} \operatornamewithlimits\int_{\gamma,\,\,y>y'+h} \Theta\,(z,\,z')\,\mu\,( z'+i\xi)\,e^{2\pi iz'}\, \psi_0(z') dz'=e^{\frac{2\pi i (z+i\xi)}h} a+ o\left(e^{-\frac{2\pi y}h}\right)$$ with $a$ from [eq:a]. Estimates [I(tilde-mu):up]–[I(tilde-mu):down] imply the second estimate in [psi-0:up:I].

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the upper half-plane
text:
*Proof.* Let us estimate $I(\tilde\mu)$. We assume that $y+\xi>0$. Using [est:theta],  [mu-est:rough] and [est:psi-a:2], we get $$\begin{gathered} |I(\tilde \mu)(z)|\le H\left( \int_{y}^\infty (1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi (y'+\xi)}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'\right.\\ \hspace{3cm}+\int_{-\xi}^y e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}(1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi (y'+\xi)}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'\\ \left.+\int_{-Y}^{-\xi} e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}(1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-2\pi y'}dy'\right). \end{gathered}$$ The expression in the brackets is bounded by $$\int_{y}^\infty e^{-2\pi y'}dy'+ \int_{-\xi}^y e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'+ (1+|Y-\xi|^2)\int_{-Y}^{-\xi} e^{-\frac{2\pi(y-y')}h}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'.$$ As $h<1$, this implies the first estimate from [psi-0:up:I]. Let us turn to $I(\mu)$. Arguing as when estimating $I(\tilde \mu)$, we check that $$\begin{gathered} \label{I(tilde-mu):up} % \left|\int_{\gamma,\,\,y'>y+h} \Theta\,(z,\,z')\,\mu\,( z'+i\xi)\,e^{2\pi iz'}\,\psi_0(z') dz'\right|\le\\ \le H\int_{y+h}^\infty (1+|y'+\xi|)^2e^{-\frac{2\pi (y'+\xi)}h-2\pi (y'+\xi)}e^{-2\pi y'}dy'=o(e^{-\frac{2\pi y}h}) % \end{gathered}$$ uniformly in $x$ as $y\to+\infty$. Then, using the estimate $$\left|\Theta(z,z')-2ie^{-\frac{2\pi i(z'-z)}h}\right|\le C e^{-\frac{4\pi (y-y')}h},\quad y-y'\ge h,$$ and again arguing as before, we prove that as $y\to\infty$, uniformly in $x$ $$\label{I(tilde-mu):down} \operatornamewithlimits\int_{\gamma,\,\,y>y'+h} \Theta\,(z,\,z')\,\mu\,( z'+i\xi)\,e^{2\pi iz'}\, \psi_0(z') dz'=e^{\frac{2\pi i (z+i\xi)}h} a+ o\left(e^{-\frac{2\pi y}h}\right)$$ with $a$ from [eq:a]. Estimates [I(tilde-mu):up]–[I(tilde-mu):down] imply the second estimate in [psi-0:up:I]. Let us prove [est:a]. Using [eq:a] and estimates [mu-est:rough] and [est:psi-a:2], we get $$|a|\le H(1+|\xi|)^2 \operatornamewithlimits\int_{-Y}^{-\xi} e^{\frac{2\pi(1-2{\rm Re}\,p) (y'+\xi)}h-2\pi y'} dy' + H\operatornamewithlimits\int_{-\xi}^{+\infty} e^{-2\pi (2y'+\xi)}(1+|y'+\xi|)^2 dy'.$$ One has $\max_{0\le y'\le-\xi} e^{\frac{2\pi(1-2{\rm Re}\,p) (y'+\xi)}h- 2\pi y'}= e^{2\pi \nu(p)\xi}=\lambda^{\nu(p)}$ with $\nu(p)$ defined by the second formula in [est:a]. Furthermore, the second integral in the last estimate for $a$ equals $\lambda\int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-4\pi t}(1+t)^2 dt$. These observations lead to [est:a]. This completes the proof of the lemma. ◻ Let us turn to the terms $J(\mu)$ and $J(\tilde\mu)$. One has
**Lemma 14**. *Fix $\delta\in(0,1)$. Let $p\in P$. As $y\to+\infty$, one has $$\label{psi-0:up:J} J(\tilde\mu)(z)=o(1),\quad J(\mu)(z)=o(e^{-\frac{2\pi y}h}).$$ These estimates are uniform in $x\in[-\delta h,\delta h]$.*

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the upper half-plane
text: *Proof.* Let $y+\xi\ge h$. Using estimates [mu-est] for $d\mu/dz$ and estimate [est:psi-a:2], we get $$|J(\mu)|\le H(1+|y+\xi|)^2e^{2\pi \delta (y+\xi)-\frac{2\pi (y+\xi)}h-2\pi (y+\xi)-2\pi y} (1+|y+\xi|)^2 \le He^{-\frac{2\pi (y+\xi)}h-2\pi y},$$ where we used the inequalities $|x|\le \delta h$ and $0<\delta<1$. This implies the first estimate in [psi-0:up:J]. Similarly one proves the second one. ◻

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the upper half-plane
text: Now we are ready to prove [psi-0:up]. We do it in three steps. Below we assume that $p\in P$. All the $o(1)$ are uniform in $x$. **1.**  Fix $\delta\in(0,1)$. Let $|x|\le\delta h$. Estimates [psi-0:up:I] and [psi-0:up:J] imply that as $y\to\infty$ $$\label{psi-0:up:delta-vic} \psi_0=\mu(z+i\xi)-(K\psi_0)(z)=\mu(z+i\xi)(1+o(1))+ e^{\frac{2\pi i (z+i\xi)}h} \tilde \mu(z+i\xi)(\tilde a+o(1))$$ where $\tilde a= \lambda a/(2hi \{\mu,\,\tilde \mu\})$. Representation [psi-0:up:delta-vic], and formulas [tildeMu] and [mu:up] imply [psi-0:up] with $\varkappa_0=ie^{\frac{i\pi}{4h}}\tilde a$. This completes the proof of [psi-0:up] for $x\in[-\delta h,\delta h]$. We note that [psi-0:up] implies that, for sufficiently large $y$, $$\label{est:psi:inter} |\psi_0(z)|\le C(1+|\varkappa_0|) e^{\frac{2\pi|x|(y+\xi)}h -\frac{\pi( y+\xi)}h-\pi (y+\xi)}.$$ **2.**  Now, we pick $\delta\in(1/2,1)$ and justify [psi-0:up] assuming that $h\delta \le x\le h(1+\delta)$. Let $\epsilon\in(0,1-\delta)$. We denote by $\gamma(z)$ the curve that goes first along a straight line from $i(y-h)$ to the point $z-h+\epsilon h$ and next along a straight line from this point to $i(y+h)$. One obtains representation [psi-0:up:Kpsi] with $J(f)$ defined by the new formula: $$\label{new:J} J(f)(z)=\int_{\gamma(z)}\Theta\,(z,\,z')\, f\,(z'+i\xi)\, e^{2\pi iz'}\,\psi_0(z') dz'.$$ We note that on $\gamma(z)$, one has $|\Theta\,(z,\,z')|\le C$. As $$-\delta h\le (\delta-1) h< x-h+\epsilon h\le (\delta+\epsilon)h,$$ and as $\delta+\epsilon<1$, we can and do assume that on $\gamma(z)$ for sufficiently large $y$ solution $\psi_0$ satisfies [est:psi:inter]. Using [est:psi:inter] and [mu-est], we check that as $y\to+\infty$ $$|J(\mu)(z)|\le H(1+|\varkappa_0|) e^{4\pi (\delta+\epsilon-1) (y+\xi)-\frac{2\pi(y+\xi)}h+2\pi \xi}(1+|y+\xi|)^2= o(e^{-\frac{2\pi(y+\xi)}h}).$$ Reasoning analogously, we also prove that $J(\tilde\mu)(z)=o(1)$ as $y\to+\infty$. These two estimates and [psi-0:up:I] lead again to [psi-0:up]. This completes the proof of [psi-0:up] for $0\le x\le (1+\delta)h$. The case of $(1+\delta)h\le x\le 0$ is analyzed similarly. **3.**  To justify [psi-0:up] for larger $|x|$, one uses equation [pert-model]. We discuss only the case of $x\ge 0$ and omit further details. Pick $\delta\in(0,1)$ and $X>0$. In the case of Theorem [psi-0:up], we can assume that $|\varkappa_0|\le 1/2$. Then, $1+\varkappa_0\ne 0$ and for $x\in [\delta h, X]$ [psi-0:up] actually means that $$\psi_0(z)=A\xi_-(z+i\xi)(1+o(1)),\qquad A=e^{\frac{i\pi}4}(1+\varkappa_0)v_-\,.$$ By [pert-model], one can write $$\psi_0(z)=-\lambda e^{-2\pi i(z-h)}\psi_0(z-h)\,\left(1+o(1)+ e^{2\pi i(z+i\xi-h)}\,\psi_0(z-2h)/\psi_0(z-h)\right).$$ Let $(1+\delta)h\le x\le (2+\delta)h$. Then $\psi_0(z-h)=A\xi_-(z+i\xi-h)(1+o(1))$. This and [est:psi:inter] (that is valid on any given compact subinterval of $(-h,h)$) imply that $e^{2\pi i z}\psi_0(z-2h)/\psi_0(z-h)=o(1)$. Therefore, $$\psi_0(z)=-\lambda\,e^{-2\pi i(z-h)}\psi_0(z-h)\,(1+o(1))=A\xi_-(z+i\xi)(1+o(1)).$$ So, we proved [psi-0:up] for $x\in[0,(2+\delta)h]$. Continuing in this way, one proves [psi-0:up] for all $x$ such that $0\le x\le X$. This completes the proof of [psi-0:up].0◻

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the lower half-plane
text: ## Asymptotics in the lower half-plane Here, we prove the third statement of Theorem 7, i.e., estimate [psi-0:down]. We pick $X>0$ and a sufficiently large $Y>0$ and assume that $|x|\le X$ and $|y|\le Y/2$. We also assume that $\lambda$ is so small (or $\lambda \le e^{C/h}$ with $C$ so large) that $Y<-\xi$.

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the lower half-plane
Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the lower half-plane
text: The proof follows the same plan and uses the same estimates for $\mu$, $\tilde \mu$ and $\psi_0$ as for studying $\psi_0$ as $y\to\infty$. So, we omit elementary details. **1.**  First, we represent $K\psi_0$ in the form [psi-0:up:Kpsi] with $I$ and $J$ given by [eq:I]– [eq:J]. Then, using [mu-est:rough] and [est:psi-a:2] and the rough estimate $|\Theta(z,z')|\le C$ for $|y-y'|\ge h$, we get $$\label{psi-0:down:ItildeI} |I(\tilde \mu)(z)|\le H (1+|\xi|)^2,\quad |I(\mu)(z)|\le H (1+|\xi|)^2\,e^{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p |\xi|/h}.$$ **2.**  Let us turn to the terms $J(\mu)$ and $J(\tilde \mu)$. We first fix a positive $\delta<1$, and consider the case where $|x|\le \delta h$. By means of Lemma 7 and [est:psi-a:2] , we get $$\label{psi-0:down:J's} |J(\tilde\mu)(z)|\le H\,(1+|\xi|)^2,\quad |J(\mu)(z)|\le H\,(1+|\xi|)^2\, e^{4\pi{\rm Re}\,p |\xi|/h}.$$ **3.** We recall that $\psi_0(z)-\mu(z+i\xi)=K\psi_0(z)$. Estimating the right hand side by means of [psi-0:down:ItildeI]–[psi-0:down:J's], the estimate from Lemma 7 for $\mu$ and [tildeMu], the definition of $\tilde \mu$, we get $$\label{psi-0:down:delta-vic} |\psi_0(z)-\mu(z+i\xi)|\le \lambda H (1+|\xi|)^3\,e^{2\pi{\rm Re}\,p |\xi|/h},$$ i.e., representation [psi-0:down] for $|x|\le \delta h$ **4.**  Now, we pick $\delta\in(1/2,1)$ and justify [psi-0:down:delta-vic] for $|x|\le (1+\delta)h$. As $|y|5.4, and redefine $J$ by [new:J]. We can and do assume that estimate [psi-0:down:delta-vic] is proved on $\gamma(z)$. This estimate and [mu-est] imply that on $\gamma(z)$ one has $|\psi_0(z)|\le H(1+|\xi|)e^{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p |\xi|/h}$. Using this and [mu-est] we obtain for the new $J(\mu)$ and $J(\tilde \mu)$ the old estimates [psi-0:down:J's], and, therefore, we come to [psi-0:down:delta-vic] for $\delta h\le x\le (1+\delta)h$. The case of negative $x$ is treated similarly. **5.**  Let us prove [psi-0:down:delta-vic] for all $|x|\le X$. Therefore, we use a difference analog of the Grönwall’s inequality. We discuss only the case where $x>0$. The case of $x<0$ is treated similarly.

section_path: Analytic solution to Harper equation / Asymptotics in the lower half-plane
text: We can and do assume that estimate [psi-0:down:delta-vic] is proved on $\gamma(z)$. This estimate and [mu-est] imply that on $\gamma(z)$ one has $|\psi_0(z)|\le H(1+|\xi|)e^{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p |\xi|/h}$. Using this and [mu-est] we obtain for the new $J(\mu)$ and $J(\tilde \mu)$ the old estimates [psi-0:down:J's], and, therefore, we come to [psi-0:down:delta-vic] for $\delta h\le x\le (1+\delta)h$. The case of negative $x$ is treated similarly. **5.**  Let us prove [psi-0:down:delta-vic] for all $|x|\le X$. Therefore, we use a difference analog of the Grönwall’s inequality. We discuss only the case where $x>0$. The case of $x<0$ is treated similarly. Let $\delta(z)=\psi_0(z)-\mu(z+i\xi)$. Equations [eq:harper] and [mu:eq] for $\psi_0$ and $\mu$ imply that $$\delta(z+h)+\delta(z-h)+2(\lambda\cos(2\pi z)-\cos(2\pi p))\delta(z)= -\lambda e^{2\pi iz}\mu(z+i\xi).$$ Therefore, $$\Delta(z+h)=M(z)\Delta (z) -\lambda e^{2\pi iz}\mu(z+i\xi)\,e_1,$$ where $$\Delta(z)=\begin{pmatrix} \delta(z)\\ \delta(z-h)\end{pmatrix},\quad M(z)=\begin{pmatrix} 2(\cos(2\pi p)-\lambda\cos(2\pi z))& -1\\1& 0\end{pmatrix},\quad e_1=\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix}.$$ Let $n(z)=\|\Delta(z)\|_{{\mathbb C}^2}$ and $A=\max_{|y|\le Y}\|M(z)\|$, where $\|\cdot\|$ is the Hilbert-Schmidt norm. In view of [mu-est] we obtain $$\label{ineq:n} n(z)\le B+A\, n(z-h),\quad B=\lambda(1+|\xi|) H e^{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p|\xi|/h}.$$ Therefore, for $N\in{\mathbb N}$, we have $$\label{ineq:n-mult} n(z)\le B\,(1+A+...A^{N-1})+ A^N\, n(z-Nh)=B\frac{A^N-1}{A-1}+A^N\,n(z-Nh).$$ Assume that $\frac{3h}2\le x \le X$ and choose $N$ so that $\frac h2\le x-Nh\le \frac{3h}2$. Then, $\bullet$  by [psi-0:down:delta-vic],  $n(z-Nh)\le \lambda H (1+|\xi|)^3\,e^{2\pi {\rm Re}\,p |\xi|/h}$; $\bullet$  $1\le N\le C/h$, and $A^N\le H$. Using these observations and the estimate for $B$ from [ineq:n], we deduce from [ineq:n-mult] estimate [psi-0:down:delta-vic] for $0\le x\le X$. This completes the proof of Theorem 7.

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation
text: # A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation Here we give a definition of the minimal entire solutions to the Harper equation and describe the monodromy matrix corresponding to a basis of two minimal entire solutions. This is the matrix described in Theorem 1. Then, we prove Theorem 2.

heading.title: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices
text: ## Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices In  the authors studied entire solutions to equation [eq:matrix] with an $SL(2,{\mathbb C})$-valued $2\pi$-periodic entire function $M$. Using the equivalence described in Section 3.1.3, we turn their results into results for the Harper equation. Let $Y\in\mathbb R$. Below, $\mathbb C_+(Y)=\{z\in\mathbb C\,:\, y>Y\}$ and $\mathbb C_-(Y)=\{z\in\mathbb C\,:\, y

heading.title: Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices / Solutions with the simplest behavior as $y\to\pm\infty$
text:
### Solutions with the simplest behavior as $y\to\pm\infty$ To characterize the behavior of an entire solution as $y\to\pm \infty$, we express it in terms of solutions having the simplest asymptotic behavior as $y\to\pm \infty$. Let us describe these solutions. The next theorem follows from Theorem 1.1a from .
**Theorem 8**. *If $Y_1>0$ is sufficiently large, there exist two solutions $u_\pm$ to [eq:harper] that are analytic in the half-plane ${\mathbb C}_+(Y_1)$ and admit there the representations $$\label{f-solutions} u_\pm(z)=e^{\textstyle \pm\frac{ i\pi}{h}\,(z-\frac12+i\xi)^2+i\pi z+o\,(1)},\quad y\to+\infty.$$ One has $$\label{eq:Wronsk-f} \{u_+(z),u_-(z)\}=\lambda.$$ Moreover, $u_\pm$ are Bloch solutions in the sense of , i.e., the ratios $u_\pm(z+1)/u_\pm(z)$ are $h$-periodic in $z$.*
**Remark 3**. The expressions $u_\pm^0(z)=e^{\textstyle\pm\frac{i\pi}{h}\,(z-\frac12+i\xi)^2+i\pi z}$, the leading terms in [f-solutions], satisfy the equations $u^0_\pm(z\mp h)+\lambda e^{-2\pi iz}\,u^0_\pm(z)=0$ (compare it with the Harper equation!).
We construct two solutions with the simplest asymptotic behavior as $y\to-\infty$ by the formulas $$\label{eq:g-sol} d_\pm(z)=-u_\pm(1-z),\qquad z\in \mathbb C_-(-Y_1).$$ We use
**Lemma 15**. *One has $$\label{u-ast-d} d_\pm^*(z)=\alpha_\pm(z)u_\mp(z),\qquad z\in\mathbb C_+(Y_1),$$ where $\alpha_\pm$ are analytic and $h$-periodic functions, and, as $y\to\infty$,  $\alpha(z)\to 1$ uniformly in $x$.*

heading.title: Solutions with the simplest behavior as $y\to\pm\infty$

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices / Solutions with the simplest behavior as $y\to\pm\infty$
text: *Proof.* We check [u-ast-d] for $d_+$. Mutatis mutandis, for $d_-$, the analysis is the same. As $\{u_+(z),u_-(z)\}$, the Wronskian of $u_+$ and $u_-$, does not vanish in $\mathbb C(Y_1)$, one has (see section 3.1.3) $$d_+^*(z)=\alpha(z) u_-(z)+\beta(z) u_+(z), \quad \alpha(z)=\frac{\{u_+(z), d_+^*(z)\}}{\{u_+(z), u_-(z)\}}, \ \ \beta(z)=\frac{\{d_+^*(z), u_-(z)\}}{\{u_+(z), u_-(z)\}}.$$ The coefficients $\alpha$ and $\beta$ are $h$-periodic and analytic in ${\mathbb C}_+(Y_1)$. We recall that $u_-$ is a Bloch solution. It means that the ratio $r(z)=u_-(z+1)/u_-(z)$ is $h$-periodic. Using [f-solutions], we get the asymptotic representation $$r(z)=-\lambda^{1/h}e^{-2\pi i z/h+o(1)},\quad y\to\infty,$$ where the error estimate is uniform in $x$. This implies that, for sufficiently large $y$, the solution $u_-$ tends to zero as $x\to-\infty$. Similarly one proves that $d_+^*$ does the same. Therefore, being periodic, the Wronskian $\{d_+^*(z), u_-(z)\}$ equals zero. This implies that $\beta=0$. Using [f-solutions], we check that as $y\to\infty$ one has $\alpha(z)=1+o(1)$ uniformly in $x$. ◻

heading.title: Solutions with the simplest behavior as $y\to\pm\infty$

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices / The minimal solutions
text: ### The minimal solutions Let $\psi$ be an entire solution to [eq:harper], and let $Y_1$ be as in Theorem 8. Then, $\psi$ admits the representations: $$\begin{gathered} % \label{psi:up} % \psi(z)=A(z)\,u_+(z)+B(z)\,u_-(z),\quad z\in \mathbb C_+(Y_1),\\ % \label{psi:down} \psi(z)=C(z)d_+(z)+D(z)\,d_-(z),\quad z\in \mathbb C_-(-Y_1), \end{gathered}$$ where $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$ are analytic and $h$-periodic in $z$. The solution $\psi$ is called *minimal* if $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$ are bounded and one of them tends to zero as $y$ tends to either $-\infty$ or $+\infty$. Let $\psi$ be a minimal solution such that $\lim_{y\to-\infty}D(z)=0$ and $C(-i\infty)=\lim_{y\to-\infty}C(z)\ne0$. We set $\psi_D(z)=\psi(z)/C(-i\infty)$. In section 7, for sufficiently small $\lambda$, we construct $\psi_D$ in terms of the solution $\psi_0$ from section 5. Let $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$ be defined for $\psi=\psi_D$ by [psi:up] and [psi:down]. The limits $$A_D=\lim_{y\to\infty}A(z), \ B_D=\lim_{y\to\infty}B(z), \ C_D=\lim_{y\to-\infty}C(z), \ D_D=\lim_{y\to-\infty} e^{2\pi iz/h}D(z)$$ are called the *asymptotic coefficients* of $\psi_D$. By definition of $\psi_D$ one has $C_D=1$.

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Minimal entire solutions and monodromy matrices / The monodromy matrix
text:
### The monodromy matrix In terms of $\psi_D$, we define one more solution to the Harper equation [eq:harper] by the formula $$\label{eq:psiB} \psi_B(z)=\psi_D(1-z).$$ Clearly, $\psi_B$ is one more minimal entire solution. Theorem 7.2 from  can be formulated as follows:
**Theorem 9**. *The minimal entire solutions $\psi_D$ and $\psi_B$ exist. They, their asymptotic coefficients and their Wronskian are nontrivial meromorphic functions of $E$. The Wronskian is independent of $z$. The monodromy matrix corresponding to $\psi_D$ and $\psi_B$ is of the form [firstM], and $$\label{first:ts} s=-\lambda_1\frac{D_D}{B_D},\quad\quad t= -\lambda_1\,{A_D},\quad\quad \lambda_1=\lambda^{\frac1h}=e^{\frac{2\pi\xi}h}.$$*
In the case of $\lambda=1$, the analysis of the poles of $s$ and $t$ was done in . Mutatis mutandis, it can be done similarly in the general case. One can see that $s$ and $t$ are analytic on the interval $I=[-2-2\lambda, 2+2\lambda]$. In section 7, as $\lambda\to 0$, we compute the asymptotics of $s$ and $t$ for $E\in I$ and so check independently their analyticity.

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Symmetries and the monodromy matrix
text: ## Symmetries and the monodromy matrix For a function $f$ of $z$ and $E$, we let $f^*(z,E)=\overline{f(\bar z,\,\bar E)}$. It is clear that $f$ and $f^*$ satisfy [eq:harper] simultaneously. Here, using this symmetry, we prove Theorem 2.

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Symmetries and the monodromy matrix / A relation for the monodromy matrix
text:
### A relation for the monodromy matrix Let us consider $E$ such that $\psi_D$ and $\psi_B$ form a basis in the space of solutions to Harper equation. The monodromy matrix corresponding to this basis is defined by [eq:MM-def] with $\psi_1=\psi_D$ and $\psi_2=\psi_B$. Below we denote it by $M$ (instead of $M_1$). As $\psi_D^*$ and $\psi_B^*$ also are solutions to Harper equation, one can write $$\label{S1:def} \Psi^*(z)= S(z/h)\Psi(z),\quad \Psi^*(z)=\begin{pmatrix} \psi_D^*(z)\\ \psi_B^*(z)\end{pmatrix},$$ where $S$ is a $2\times2$ matrix with $1$-periodic entries. It is entire in $z$ and meromorphic in $E$ like the basis solutions. One has
**Lemma 16**. *The matrices $M$ and $S$ satisfy the relation $$\label{M:sym} S(z+h_1)\,M(z)= M^*(z)\,S(z),\qquad h_1=\{1/h\},$$ where $M^*$ is obtained from $M$ by applying the operation ${}^*$ to each of its entries.*
*Proof.* The definition of the monodromy matrix and [S1:def] imply that $$S\left((z+1)/h \right)\,M(z/h)\,\Psi(z) = M^*(z/h)\,S(z/h)\,\Psi(z).$$ Let $(\Psi(z+h), \Psi(z))$ be the matrix made of the column vectors $\Psi(z+h)$ and $\Psi(z)$. As the functions $S$ and $M$ are $1$-periodic, we get $$S\left((z+1)/h \right)\,M(z/h)\,(\Psi(z+h),\Psi(z)) = M^*(z/h)\,S(z/h)\,(\Psi(z+h),\Psi(z)).$$ As $$\det (\Psi(z+h), \Psi(z))=\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\},$$ the determinant of $(\Psi(z+h),\Psi(z))$ is nontrivial, and we come to the relation $S\left(z/h+1/h \right)\,M(z/h)= M^*(z/h)\,S(z/h).$ As $S$ is $1$-periodic, it implies [M:sym]. ◻

heading.title: A relation for the monodromy matrix

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Properties of the matrix *S*
text:
## Properties of the matrix *S* We start with the following elementary observation.
**Lemma 17**. *One has $$\label{eq:S-prop} \sigma_1\,S(h_1-z)\,\sigma_1=S(z),\quad \sigma_1=\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 &0 \end{pmatrix}.$$*
*Proof.* In view of [eq:psiB], one has $\Psi(1-z)=\sigma_1\Psi(z)$. This and [S1:def] imply that $\Psi^*(z)=\sigma_1 S(h_1-z/h)\sigma_1 \Psi(z)$. Using [S1:def] once more, we obtain the relation $S(z/h)\Psi(z)=\sigma_1 S(h_1-z/h)\sigma_1 \Psi(z)$. Using the argument from the end of the proof of Lemma 16, we deduce [eq:S-prop] from this relation. The proof is complete. ◻
Now, we check
**Proposition 7**. *The entries of $S$ are independent of $z$. One has $$\begin{gathered} \label{eq:SIJ} S_{11}=S_{22}=\frac1{B_D},\qquad S_{12}=S_{21} =\frac{A_D}{B_D},\\ \label{ADandBD} A_D^*=A_D,\qquad B_DB_D^*-A_DA_D^*=1. \end{gathered}$$*

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Properties of the matrix *S*
text: *Proof.* We prove formulas [eq:SIJ] for $S_{11}$ and $S_{12}$. These formulas and relation [eq:S-prop] imply the formulas for the other entries of $M$. According to [eq:three-solutions]– [eq:periodic-coef], relation [S1:def] implies that $$\label{eq:S-wronsk} S_{11}(z/h)=\frac{\{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}}{\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}}, \qquad S_{12}(z/h)=\frac{\{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}}{\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}}.$$ Below, we compute the Wronskians in [eq:S-wronsk] in terms of the asymptotic coefficients of the solution $\Psi_D$.

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Properties of the matrix *S*
text: *Proof.* We prove formulas [eq:SIJ] for $S_{11}$ and $S_{12}$. These formulas and relation [eq:S-prop] imply the formulas for the other entries of $M$. According to [eq:three-solutions]– [eq:periodic-coef], relation [S1:def] implies that $$\label{eq:S-wronsk} S_{11}(z/h)=\frac{\{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}}{\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}}, \qquad S_{12}(z/h)=\frac{\{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}}{\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}}.$$ Below, we compute the Wronskians in [eq:S-wronsk] in terms of the asymptotic coefficients of the solution $\Psi_D$. Let us begin with $\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}$. We recall that, for sufficiently large $Y_1$, solution $\psi=\psi_D$ admits representations [psi:up] and [psi:down] with $h$-periodic coefficients $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$, and $D=e^{-2\pi i z/h}D_1(z)$, where $D_1$ is bounded in $\mathbb C_-(-Y_1)$. By means of [eq:psiB] and [eq:g-sol] we get for $z\in \mathbb C_+(Y_1)$ $$\begin{split} \{\psi_D(z)&,\psi_B(z)\}=\\ &=\left\{A(z)u_+(z)+B(z)u_-(z), -C(1-z)u_+(z)-e^{-\frac{2\pi i (1-z)}h}D_1(1-z)u_-(z)\right\}\\ &=\left(-e^{-\frac{2\pi i (1-z)}h}A(z)D_1(1-z)+B(z) C(1-z)\right)\left\{u_+(z),u_-(z)\right\}. \end{split}$$ Using this representation, ([eq:Wronsk-f]) and the definitions of the asymptotic coefficients of $\psi_D$, see [s:min-sol], we check that $$\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}\to\lambda B_DC_D=\lambda B_D\quad \text{as}\quad y\to\infty.$$ Similarly, we prove that $$\begin{gathered} \{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\\ =\left\{C(z)d_+(z)+e^{-2\pi i z/h}D_1(z)d_-(z), -A(1-z)d_+(z)-B(1-z)d_-(z)\right\}\\ \longrightarrow \quad \lambda B_D \qquad \text{as} \qquad y\to-\infty. \end{gathered}$$ As $\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}$ is an $h$-periodic entire function, these observations imply that $$\label{W:DB} \{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda B_D.$$ By means of Lemma 15, one similarly computes the Wronskians $\{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}$ and $\{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}$, and obtains the formulas $$\begin{gathered} \{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda+o(1)\quad\text{as}\quad y\to+\infty,\\ \{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda( B_DB_D^*-A_DA_D^*)+o(1)\quad \text{as}\quad y\to-\infty,\\ \intertext{and} \{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}=\lambda A_D+o(1)\quad\text{as}\quad y\to+\infty,\\ \{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}=-\lambda A_D^*+o(1)\quad \text{as}\quad y\to-\infty. \end{gathered}$$ The last four formulas imply [ADandBD] and formulas $$\{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda,\quad \{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}=\lambda A_D.$$ This, [W:DB] and [eq:S-wronsk] imply [eq:SIJ]. ◻

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Properties of the matrix *S*
text: Let us begin with $\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}$. We recall that, for sufficiently large $Y_1$, solution $\psi=\psi_D$ admits representations [psi:up] and [psi:down] with $h$-periodic coefficients $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$, and $D=e^{-2\pi i z/h}D_1(z)$, where $D_1$ is bounded in $\mathbb C_-(-Y_1)$. By means of [eq:psiB] and [eq:g-sol] we get for $z\in \mathbb C_+(Y_1)$ $$\begin{split} \{\psi_D(z)&,\psi_B(z)\}=\\ &=\left\{A(z)u_+(z)+B(z)u_-(z), -C(1-z)u_+(z)-e^{-\frac{2\pi i (1-z)}h}D_1(1-z)u_-(z)\right\}\\ &=\left(-e^{-\frac{2\pi i (1-z)}h}A(z)D_1(1-z)+B(z) C(1-z)\right)\left\{u_+(z),u_-(z)\right\}. \end{split}$$ Using this representation, ([eq:Wronsk-f]) and the definitions of the asymptotic coefficients of $\psi_D$, see [s:min-sol], we check that $$\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}\to\lambda B_DC_D=\lambda B_D\quad \text{as}\quad y\to\infty.$$ Similarly, we prove that $$\begin{gathered} \{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\\ =\left\{C(z)d_+(z)+e^{-2\pi i z/h}D_1(z)d_-(z), -A(1-z)d_+(z)-B(1-z)d_-(z)\right\}\\ \longrightarrow \quad \lambda B_D \qquad \text{as} \qquad y\to-\infty. \end{gathered}$$ As $\{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}$ is an $h$-periodic entire function, these observations imply that $$\label{W:DB} \{\psi_D(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda B_D.$$ By means of Lemma 15, one similarly computes the Wronskians $\{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}$ and $\{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}$, and obtains the formulas $$\begin{gathered} \{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda+o(1)\quad\text{as}\quad y\to+\infty,\\ \{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda( B_DB_D^*-A_DA_D^*)+o(1)\quad \text{as}\quad y\to-\infty,\\ \intertext{and} \{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}=\lambda A_D+o(1)\quad\text{as}\quad y\to+\infty,\\ \{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}=-\lambda A_D^*+o(1)\quad \text{as}\quad y\to-\infty. \end{gathered}$$ The last four formulas imply [ADandBD] and formulas $$\{\psi_D^*(z),\psi_B(z)\}=\lambda,\quad \{\psi_D(z),\psi_D^*(z)\}=\lambda A_D.$$ This, [W:DB] and [eq:S-wronsk] imply [eq:SIJ]. ◻

section_path: A monodromy matrix for the Harper equation / Properties of the matrix *S* / Proof of Theorem 2
text: ### Proof of Theorem 2 Formulas [M:sym] and [eq:SIJ] imply the relation $$\tilde S\,M(z)= M^*(z)\,\tilde S,\quad \forall z\in{\mathbb C},\qquad \tilde S=\begin{pmatrix} 1 & A_D\\ A_D & 1 \end{pmatrix}.$$ This relation implies that $$M_{12}(z)+A_D M_{22}(z)=M_{11}^*(z) A_D+ M_{12}^*(z), \qquad \forall z\in{\mathbb C}.$$ Substituting into this formula the expressions for the monodromy matrix entries from [firstM], we get $$% s+te^{-2\pi i z} +A_D\frac{st}{\lambda_1}= A_D\big(a^*-2\lambda_1\cos(2\pi z)\big)+s^*+t^*e^{2\pi i z},\qquad \forall z\in{\mathbb C}.$$ This equality of two trigonometric polynomials leads to the relations $$% t=-\lambda_1A_D,\quad s+A_D\frac{st}\lambda_1=a^*A_D+s^*.$$ The first of these two relations and the first formula in [ADandBD] imply that $t=-t^*$, and substituting in the second one the formula $A_D=-t/\lambda_1$ and the formula for $a$ from [firstM], one easily checks that $$ss^*=\lambda_1^2\frac{1-t^2}{\lambda_1^2-t^2}.$$ These two observations imply [eq:s/a]. Let $E\in {\mathbb R}$. One has $t=i\tau$ and $s=-i\lambda_1\sqrt{\frac{1-t^2}{\lambda_1^2-t^2}} e^{i\alpha}$ with real $\tau$ and $\alpha$. Using these representations, we get the formula [trace]: $$L=\frac{\lambda_1}{st}\,\big(1-s^2-t^2\big)+\frac{st}{\lambda_1}= \frac{2}{\tau}\sqrt{(1+\tau^2)(\lambda_1+\tau^2)}\cos \alpha.$$ The proof of Theorem 2 is complete.0◻

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem
text:
## Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem

Fix $Y>0$. Below $\mathbb C_+={\mathbb C}_+(-Y)$ and $\mathbb C_-={\mathbb C}_-(Y)$. To construct the solution $\psi_D$, we paste it of solutions analytic in $\mathbb C_+$ and solutions analytic in $\mathbb C_-$ by means of a Riemann-Hilbert problem. Here, we formulate this problem.

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem / Relations between entire solutions and solutions analytic in ${\mathbb C}_\pm$

heading.title: Relations between entire solutions and solutions analytic in ${\mathbb C}_\pm$

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem / Relations between entire solutions and solutions analytic in ${\mathbb C}_\pm$
text:
Let $\sigma$ be either the sign “$+$” or the sign “$-$”. Let $\mathbb{S}_\sigma$ be the set of solutions to Harper equation that are analytic in ${\mathbb C}_\sigma$, and let $\mathbb{K}_\sigma$ be the set of the complex valued functions that are analytic and $h$-periodic in in ${\mathbb C}_\sigma$. Assume that $\psi_\sigma$ and $\phi_\sigma$ belong $\mathbb{S}_\sigma$. Let $w_\sigma(z)=\{\psi_\sigma(z),\phi_\sigma(z)\}$. One has $w_\sigma\in\mathbb{K}_\sigma$. We assume that $w_\sigma$ does not vanish in ${\mathbb C}_\sigma$. Then, the pair $\psi_\sigma,\,\phi_\sigma$ is a basis in $\mathbb{S}_\sigma$. Any entire solution $\psi$ to [eq:matrix] admits the representations $$\label{RP:1} \psi\,(z)=a_+(z)\,\psi_+(z)+b_+(z)\,\phi_+(z), \quad z\in{\mathbb C}_+,\qquad a_+,\,b_+\in{\mathbb{K}}_+,$$ $$\label{RP:2} \psi\,(z)=a_-(z)\,\psi_-(z)+b_-(z)\,\phi_-(z),\quad z\in{\mathbb C}_-,\qquad a_-,\,b_-\in{\mathbb{K}}_-,$$ with $$% a_\pm(z)=\frac1{w_\pm(z)}\{\psi\,(z),\,\phi_\pm(z)\},\quad b_\pm(z)=\frac1{w_\pm(z)}\{\psi_\pm(z),\,\psi\,(z)\}.$$ It follows from  [RP:1] and [RP:2] that $$\label{RP:3} a_+(z)\,\psi_+(z)+b_+(z)\,\phi_+(z)=a_-(z)\,\psi_-(z)+b_-(z)\,\phi_-(z), \quad z\in{\mathbb R}.$$ This implies that $$\label{RP:4} V_+=\,G\,V_-,\quad z\in{\mathbb R},\quad\quad V_+=\left(\begin{array}{c} a_+\\ b_+\end{array}\right),\quad V_-=\left(\begin{array}{c} a_-\\ b_-\end{array}\right),$$ where $G$ is the matrix with the entries $$\label{RP:5} \begin{array}{ll} G_{11}(z)=\frac1{w_+(z)}\,\{\psi_-(z),\,\phi_+(z)\}, & G_{12}(z)=\frac1{w_+(z)}\,\{\phi_-(z),\,\phi_+(z)\},\\ G_{21}(z)=\frac1{w_+(z)}\,\{\psi_+(z),\,\psi_-(z)\},& G_{22}(z)=\frac1{w_+(z)}\,\{\psi_+(z),\,\phi_-(z)\}. \end{array}$$
**Remark 4**. One has $$\label{detG} \det G(z)= w_-(z)\,/\,w_+(z),\quad z\in{\mathbb R}.$$ Indeed, [RP:3] implies also the relation $$V_-=\frac1{w_-(z)}\,\begin{pmatrix} \{\psi_+(z),\,\phi_-(z)\} &\{\phi_+(z),\,\phi_-(z)\}\\ \{\psi_-(z),\,\psi_+(z)\}& \{\psi_-(z),\,\phi_+(z)\} \end{pmatrix}\, V_+.$$ One also can express $V_-$ via $V_+$ by inverting the matrix $G$ in [RP:4]. Comparing the results, one comes to [detG].
We have checked
**Lemma 18**. *Any entire solution to [eq:matrix] can be represented by [RP:1] – [RP:2] with $a_+,\, b_+\in{\mathbb{K}}_+$ and $a_-,\,b_-\in {\mathbb{K}}_-$, and these coefficients satisfy the relation [RP:4] with the matrix $G$ given by [RP:5].*
One can easily prove also

text: ### Basis solutions for constructing $\psi_D$ Let $\psi_0(z,p)$ be the solution to [eq:harper] described in Proposition 7, and let $$\label{0:up} \psi_+(z,p)=\psi_0(z,p),\quad \phi_+(z,p)=e^{-\frac{\pi i(z+i\xi)}h} \psi_0\,(z-1/2,1/2-p),$$ and $$\label{0:down} \psi_-(z,p)=\psi_+^*(z,\,p),\quad \phi_-(z,p)=\phi_+^*(z,\,p).$$ Clearly, $\psi_+,\,\phi_+\in{\mathbb{S}}_+$, and $\psi_-,\,\phi_-\in{\mathbb{S}}_-$. To work with $\psi_\pm$ and $\phi_\pm$, we need to describe their behavior for large $y$ and for $y\sim 0$. Theorem 7 and formulas [f-solutions] and [eq:g-sol] imply

text: **Corollary 7**. *In the case of Theorem 7, for sufficiently large $Y_1$, and for all $z\in{\mathbb C}_+(Y_1)$, one has $$\label{psi-phi-plus} \begin{split} \psi_+(z,p)=&A_\psi(z) e^{\frac{2\pi i(z+i\xi)}h} u_+(z)+B_\psi (z)u_-(z),\\ % \phi_+(z,p)&=A_\phi(z)\, u_+(z)+\,B_\phi(z)\, u_-(z). \end{split}$$ For $z\in{\mathbb C}_-(-Y_1)$, one has $$\begin{gathered} \label{psi-phi-minus} \begin{split}\textstyle \psi_-(z,p)=&\textstyle\frac{B_\psi^*(z)}{\alpha_+^*(z)}\; d_+(z)+ \frac{A_\psi^*(z)}{\alpha_-^*(z)} \;e^{-\frac{2\pi i(z-i\xi)}h} d_-(z),\\ % \phi_-(z,p)&=\textstyle\frac{B_\phi^*(z)}{\alpha_+^*(z)}\; d_+(z)+ \frac{A_\phi^*(z)}{\alpha_-^*(z)} \;d_-(z), \end{split} \end{gathered}$$ where $\alpha_\pm$, $A_\psi$, $B_\psi$, $A_\phi$ and $B_\phi$ are $h$-periodic and analytic in $z$;  $\alpha_\pm$ are described in Lemma 15, and one has $$\begin{gathered} \label{A0,B0} A_\psi(z)=A_{\psi,0}(1+o(1)),\quad B_\psi(z)=B_{\psi,0}(1+o(1)),\quad y\to+\infty,\\ \nonumber A_{\psi,0}=e^{\frac{i\pi}4-\frac{2\pi ip^2}h-\frac{i\pi}{3h}-\frac{i\pi h}{12}}\, e^{-\pi \xi},\quad B_{\psi,0}=e^{-\frac{i\pi}4-\frac{i\pi h}4-\pi\xi}(1+\varkappa_0), \\ \label{A0,B0-hats} A_\phi(z)=A_{\phi,0}(1+o(1)),\quad B_\phi(z)=B_{\phi,0}(1+o(1)),\quad y\to+\infty,\\ \nonumber A_{\phi,0}(p)=-iA_{\psi,0}(1/2-p)\,e^{-\frac{i\pi}{4h}} ,\quad B_{\phi,0}(p)=-iB_{\psi,0}(1/2-p)\,e^{-\frac{3i\pi}{4h}}. \end{gathered}$$ These asymptotics are uniform in ${\rm Re}\,z$.*

**Corollary 8**. *Let $Y$, $\lambda$ and $h$ be as in Theorem 7. Fix $\alpha\in(0,1)$ and $X>0$. For $p\in P$,  $|y|\le \frac{Y}2$ and $|x|\le X$ the following holds. $\bullet$  Pick $\beta\in(0,\alpha)$. If  ${\rm Re}\,p\ge \alpha h/2$, then $$\label{psi-plus:1} \psi_+(z)= e^{\frac{2\pi ip (z+i\xi)}h} \left(a(p)+O_H(\lambda^\beta)\right),$$ and if  ${\rm Re}\,p\le \frac12-\alpha h/2$, then $$\label{phi-plus:1} \phi_+(z)= e^{-\frac{2\pi ip (z+i\xi)}h} \left(e^{-\frac{i\pi (1/2-p)}h}a(1/2-p)+O_H(\lambda^\beta)\right). %$$ $\bullet$  Pick $\beta\in (0,1)$. If  ${\rm Re}\,p\le \alpha h/2$, then $$\label{psi-plus:2} \begin{split} \psi_+(z)= a(p)\,e^{\frac{2\pi ip (z+i\xi)}h}+a(-p)\,e^{-\frac{2\pi ip(z+i\xi)}h}&+ % O_H\left(\lambda^\beta e^{-\frac{2\pi p\xi}h}\,\right), % \end{split}$$ and if  $p\ge \pi-\alpha h/2$, then $$\label{phi-plus:2} \begin{split} \phi_+(z)= e^{-\frac{2\pi ip (z+i\xi)}h}\,&e^{-\frac{i\pi (1/2-p)}h}a(1/2-p)\\ +&e^{-\frac{2\pi i(1/2-p)(z+i\xi)}h}\,e^{\frac{i\pi (1/2-p)}h}a(p-1/2)+ % O_H\left(\lambda^\beta e^{\frac{2\pi p\xi}h}\,\right). % \end{split}$$*
We complete this section by computing the Wronskians $w_\pm=w_\pm(z)$. As $$\label{w=w} w_-(z)=w_+^*(z),$$ we need to compute only $w_+$. One has
