**Lemma 20**. *Let $Y$, $\lambda$ and $h$ be as in Theorem 7. Fix $0<\beta<1$. For $p\in P$ and $z\in{\mathbb C}_+(-Y/2)$, one has $$\label{w+} w_+= w_0+O(H\lambda^\beta),\quad % w_0=ie^{-\frac{2\pi ip^2}h+\frac{2ip\pi}h-\frac{13i\pi}{12h}-\frac{i\pi h}3}.$$*
**Remark 5**. Lemma 20 implies that $\psi_+$ and $\phi_+$ are linearly independent if $\lambda
*Proof.* First, we compute $w_+$ as $y\to+\infty$. Using [psi-phi-plus] we get $$\begin{aligned} \{\psi_+,\phi_+\}&= \left\{A_\psi e^{\frac{2\pi i(z+i\xi)}h}u_++B_\psi u_-, A_\phi u_++B_\phi u_-\right\}\\ &=\left(A_\psi B_\phi e^{\frac{2\pi i(z+i\xi)}h}-B_\psi A_\phi\right)\, \{u_+,u_-\}\\ &=-\lambda A_{\phi,0} B_{\psi,0}+o(1). \end{aligned}$$ So, the Wronskian is bounded as $y\to+\infty$. Let us pick $\beta\in(0,1)$ and check that $$\label{w-plus-and-a} w_+=2i\sin (2\pi p)\,a(p)\,a(1/2-p)\,e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}+O_H(\lambda^\beta),\quad |y|\le Y/2.$$ Note that in view of [wr-relation] this already implies representation [w+] for $|y|\le Y/2$.

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem / Basis solutions for constructing $\psi_D$
text: Let us pick $\beta\in(0,1)$ and check that $$\label{w-plus-and-a} w_+=2i\sin (2\pi p)\,a(p)\,a(1/2-p)\,e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}+O_H(\lambda^\beta),\quad |y|\le Y/2.$$ Note that in view of [wr-relation] this already implies representation [w+] for $|y|\le Y/2$. To prove [w-plus-and-a], we pick $\alpha\in(\beta,1)$ and consequently consider four cases. In the case where $\frac{\alpha h}2\le {\rm Re}\,p\le 1/2-\frac{\alpha h}2$ formula [w-plus-and-a] follows from representations [psi-plus:1], [phi-plus:1] and estimate [est:a0]. In the case where ${\rm Re}\,p\le \min\{\frac{\alpha h}2,\,\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\}$, we use representations [phi-plus:1]–[psi-plus:2] and estimates [est:a0]–[est:a_0], and get $$w_+=2i\sin(2\pi p)\,a(p)\,a(1/2-p)\,e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h} +O_H(\xi\lambda^\beta).$$ As we can assume that $\beta$ in the last formula is larger than in [w-plus-and-a], we again obtain [w-plus-and-a]. The case where ${\rm Re}\,p\ge \max\{\frac{\alpha h}2,\,\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\}$ is treated similarly (by means of [psi-plus:1] and [phi-plus:2]). Finally, let $\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\le{\rm Re}\,p\le \frac{\alpha h}2$. Note that in this case one has $h>\frac1{2\alpha}>1/2$. Now we get $$\label{5.29} \begin{split} w_+=2i&\sin(2\pi p)a(p)a(1/2-p)e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}\\ &-2i\sin(2\pi p)a(-p)a(p-1/2) e^{\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}\,e^{-\frac{2\pi i(z+i\xi)}h} +O(\xi\lambda^\beta). \end{split}$$ Let us estimate the second term in the right hand side of [5.29]. We denote it by $T$. According to [a(p,h)], for $p\in P$, we have $$|T|\le C \lambda^{1/h}\big|\sin(2\pi p)\sigma_{\pi h}(-4\pi p-\pi h-\pi) \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi (p-1/2)-\pi h-\pi)\big|.$$ By means of [eq:sigma] and [sigma:qp], we get $$% |T|\le C \lambda^{1/h}\left|\frac{\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi (h/2-p)-\pi h-\pi) \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)}{1-e^{-\frac{4\pi i p}h}}\right|.$$ As $\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\le{\rm Re}\,p\le \frac{\alpha h}2$ and $\frac12 \pi(1-\alpha), \quad 4\pi {\rm Re}\,p\ge 2\pi(1-\alpha h)\ge 2\pi(1-\alpha),\\ \pi (1-\alpha)\le {\rm Re}\,2\pi p/h\le \alpha\pi. \end{gathered}$$ The first two inequalities and Corollary 11 imply that $|\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi (h/2-p)-\pi h-\pi)\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)|\le C$. The third inequality implies that $|1-e^{-4\pi i p/h}|\ge C$. These observations prove that $|T|\le C \lambda^{1/h}$. As $1/2[w+] for $|y|\le Y/2$.

In the case where $\frac{\alpha h}2\le {\rm Re}\,p\le 1/2-\frac{\alpha h}2$ formula [w-plus-and-a] follows from representations [psi-plus:1], [phi-plus:1] and estimate [est:a0]. In the case where ${\rm Re}\,p\le \min\{\frac{\alpha h}2,\,\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\}$, we use representations [phi-plus:1]–[psi-plus:2] and estimates [est:a0]–[est:a_0], and get $$w_+=2i\sin(2\pi p)\,a(p)\,a(1/2-p)\,e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h} +O_H(\xi\lambda^\beta).$$ As we can assume that $\beta$ in the last formula is larger than in [w-plus-and-a], we again obtain [w-plus-and-a]. Finally, let $\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\le{\rm Re}\,p\le \frac{\alpha h}2$. Note that in this case one has $h>\frac1{2\alpha}>1/2$. Now we get $$\label{5.29} \begin{split} w_+=2i&\sin(2\pi p)a(p)a(1/2-p)e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}\\ &-2i\sin(2\pi p)a(-p)a(p-1/2) e^{\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}\,e^{-\frac{2\pi i(z+i\xi)}h} +O(\xi\lambda^\beta). \end{split}$$ Let us estimate the second term in the right hand side of [5.29]. We denote it by $T$. According to [a(p,h)], for $p\in P$, we have $$|T|\le C \lambda^{1/h}\big|\sin(2\pi p)\sigma_{\pi h}(-4\pi p-\pi h-\pi) \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi (p-1/2)-\pi h-\pi)\big|.$$ By means of [eq:sigma] and [sigma:qp], we get $$% |T|\le C \lambda^{1/h}\left|\frac{\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi (h/2-p)-\pi h-\pi) \sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)}{1-e^{-\frac{4\pi i p}h}}\right|.$$ As $\frac12-\frac{\alpha h}2\le{\rm Re}\,p\le \frac{\alpha h}2$ and $\frac12 \pi(1-\alpha), \quad 4\pi {\rm Re}\,p\ge 2\pi(1-\alpha h)\ge 2\pi(1-\alpha),\\ \pi (1-\alpha)\le {\rm Re}\,2\pi p/h\le \alpha\pi. \end{gathered}$$ The first two inequalities and Corollary 11 imply that $|\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi (h/2-p)-\pi h-\pi)\sigma_{\pi h}(4\pi p-\pi h-\pi)|\le C$. The third inequality implies that $|1-e^{-4\pi i p/h}|\ge C$. These observations prove that $|T|\le C \lambda^{1/h}$. As $1/2[w+] for $|y|\le Y/2$. The expression $w_+-w_0$ is $h$-periodic and analytic in $z$. Since it is bounded as $y\to+\infty$, representation [w+] justified for $y=-Y/2$ and the maximum principle imply that $w_+-w_0=O(H\lambda^\beta)$ for all $z\in {\mathbb C}_+(-Y/2)$ uniformly in $p\in P$. This completes the proof. ◻

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem / Riemann-Hilbert problem for constructing $\psi_D$
text: ### Riemann-Hilbert problem for constructing $\psi_D$

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Formulation of the Riemann-Hilbert problem / Riemann-Hilbert problem for constructing $\psi_D$
text: ### Riemann-Hilbert problem for constructing $\psi_D$ Let $\psi_\pm$ and $\phi_\pm$ be the bases chosen in section 7.1.2. The minimal solution $\psi=\psi_D$ admits the representations [RP:1]- [RP:2]. The coefficients $a_\pm,b_\pm\in\mathbb K_\pm$ satisfy the equation [RP:4] with the matrix $G$ defined by [RP:5]. To formulate the Riemann-Hilbert problem for these coefficients, we need to study their behavior at $\pm i\infty$. The coefficients $a_\pm$ and $b_\pm$ being $h$-periodic, we shall regard them as functions of the variable $\zeta=e^{2\pi i z/h}$. Let $${\mathbb T}=\{\zeta\in{\mathbb C}\,:\,|\zeta|=1\},\quad {\mathbb B}_o=\{\zeta\in{\mathbb C}\,:\,|\zeta|\le 1\},\quad {\mathbb B}_\infty=\{\zeta\in{\mathbb C}\,: |\zeta|\ge 1\}\cup\{\infty\}.$$ The function $V_+$ is analytic in ${\mathbb B}_o\setminus \{0\}$, and $V_-$ is analytic in ${\mathbb B}_\infty\setminus\{\infty\}$. Substituting [psi-phi-plus] into [RP:1], we see that if $a_+$ and $b_+$ are bounded as $\zeta\to 0$ ($y\to+\infty$), then $\psi_D$ admits representation [psi:up] with $A$ and $B$ staying bounded as $y\to+\infty$, and one has $$\label{1:RP:4} A_D=A_{\phi,0}\,b_+(0),\quad B_D=B_{\psi,0}\,a_+(0)+B_{\phi,0}\,b_+(0).$$ Substituting [psi-phi-minus] into [RP:2] and taking into account Lemma 15, we see that if, as $\zeta\to\infty$, the coefficient $a_-$ is bounded and $b_-(\zeta)\to 0$, then $\psi_D$ admits representation [psi:down] with $C$ staying bounded and $D$ vanishing as $\zeta\to \infty$. One has $$\label{1:RP:6} \begin{array}{c} 1=C_D=B_{\psi,0}^*\,a_-(\infty),\quad D_D=e^{-\frac{2\pi\xi}h}\,A_{\psi,0}^*\, a_-(\infty)+A_{\phi,0}^*\,b_{-,1},\\{}\\ b_{-,1}=\lim_{\zeta\to\infty} (\zeta b_-(\zeta)). \end{array}$$ Let us collect the obtained information on the coefficients $a_\pm$ and $b_\pm$. One has $$\begin{gathered} % \label{1:RP:b} V_+(\zeta)=G(\zeta)\,V_-(\zeta),\quad\quad \zeta\in{\mathbb T},\\ % \label{1:RP:a} V_+\text{ is analytic in } {\mathbb B}_o,\quad V_-\text{ is analytic in } {\mathbb B}_\infty, \quad \textstyle V_-(\infty)=\frac1{B_{\psi,0}^*}\begin{pmatrix} 1\\ 0\end{pmatrix}, \end{gathered}$$ Equation [1:RP:b] and conditions [1:RP:a] form a Riemann-Hilbert problem. We shall see that, for sufficiently small $\lambda$, this problem has a unique solution. Having solved this problem, we shall reconstruct the coefficients of the minimal solution $\psi_D$ by the formulae [1:RP:4] and [1:RP:6].

## Matrix G

In this section, we study the matrix $G$.

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Matrix G / Functional relations
text: ### Functional relations The properties of the matrix $G$ we discuss here immediately follow from [RP:5], [0:up] and [0:down]. When describing these properties, we use the variable $z$, assume that $\lambda[RP:5] implies that $$\begin{gathered} \label{G:r-an} g_{22}(z,p)= g_{11}^*(z,p), \ \ g_{12}(z,p)=-g_{12}^*(z,p), \ \ g_{21}(z,p)=-g_{21}^*(z,p). \end{gathered}$$ Furthermore, relation [w=w] and the formula [detG] imply that $$% \det G^*=\det G^{-1},\qquad g_{11}\,g_{22}-g_{12}\,g_{21}=w_+^*w_+.$$ Finally, as $\phi_+(z,p)=e^{-\frac{i\pi(z+i\xi)}h}\,\psi_+(z-1/2,1/2-p)$, we get $$\label{G:invers} g_{12}(z,p)=e^{\frac{2\pi\xi}h}\,g_{21}(z-1/2,1/2-p).$$

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Matrix G / The asymptotics of $G$ for $0<p<1/2$
text: ### The asymptotics of $G$ for $0 **Proposition 8**. *Let $0<\beta<1/2$. There is a constant $C$ such that if $\lambda[w+], $\delta$ denotes $O(\lambda^\beta H)$, and $F$ is the meromorphic function such that $$\label{F_1,F_2} F(p)=\left|\sigma_{\pi h}( 4\pi p-\pi-\pi h)\right|^2, \quad p \in {\mathbb R}.$$ Moreover, one has $|F(p)|\le H$ for $p\in P$ such that $h/4\le {\rm Re}\,p$.* So in the case of this proposition, for sufficiently small $\lambda$ the matrix $G$ appears to be close to a constant one.

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Matrix G / The asymptotics of $G$ for $0<p<1/2$
text: *Proof.* Below, we assume that all the hypotheses of the proposition are satisfied. First, we estimate the Wronskian $g_{11}=\{\psi_-,\phi_+\}$. Using [psi-plus:1]– [phi-plus:1] and the definition $\psi_-$ from [0:down], we get $$g_{11}= % \left\{e^{-\frac{2\pi ip(z-i\xi)}h}(a^*(p) +\delta),\ e^{-\frac{2\pi ip(z+i\xi)}h}(e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}a(1/2-p) +\delta)\right\}.$$ Obviously, the leading term equals zero, and using estimate [est:a0] we prove that $g_{11}=O(\lambda^\beta\,H)$. By means of the first relation from [G:r-an] we also see that $g_{22}=O(\lambda^\beta\,H)$. As $G_{jj}=(w_+)^{-1}g_{jj}$, $j=1,2$, and in view of Lemma 20, we get the announced estimate for the diagonal elements of the matrix $G$. Now consider $g_{12}=\{\phi_-(z),\,\phi_+(z)\}$. Using [phi-plus:1], [0:down] and [est:a0], we get $$\begin{aligned} g_{12}&= % \{e^{\frac{2\pi ip(z-i\xi)}h}(a^*(1/2-p) +\delta),\; e^{-\frac{2\pi ip(z+i\xi)}h}(a(1/2-p) +\delta) \}=\\ % &=e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\Big(2i\sin (2\pi p)\, |a(1/2-p)|^2+ O(\lambda^\beta H)\Big). % \end{aligned}$$ Let us note that, to get this formula, instead of $h/4\le p\le 1/2-h/4$, we have only to assume that ${\rm Re}\,p\le 1/2-h/4$. The definition of $a$, formula [a(p,h)], implies that $$\label{eq:F-a} F(p)=|a(p)|^2.$$ Therefore, $$\label{g12} g_{12}=e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h} \Big(2i\,F(1/2-p)\,\sin(2\pi p)+\delta\Big), %$$ and also, in view of [est:a0]  $|F(p)|\le H$ for $p\in P$ such that ${\rm Re}\,p\ge h/4$. This estimate and representations [g12] and [w+] imply the formula for $G_{12}$ announced in the proposition. We note that it is valid for all $p\in P$ such that ${\rm Re}\,p\le \pi-h/4$. Formula [g12] and relation [G:invers] imply the formula for $G_{21}$ announced in the proposition. It is valid for all $p\in P$ such that $h/4\le {\rm Re}\,p$. We have checked all the statements of the proposition. ◻

**Lemma 21**. *One has $$\label{eq:F} F(p+1/2)=4\sin^2\frac{2\pi p}h\;F(p),$$ $$\label{F1F2:rel} 4\sin^2(2\pi p)\;F(1/2-p)\,F(p)=1.$$*

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Proof of Theorem 3
text: ## Proof of Theorem 3 Here, we compute the coefficients $s$ and $t$ of the monodromy matrix in the case where $p\in P$ is bounded away from $0$ and $1/2$. Therefore, first, we solve the Riemann-Hilbert problem [1:RP:b]–[1:RP:a] to find the asymptotics of $a_+(0)$, $b_+(0)$, $a_-(\infty)$ and $\lim_{\zeta\to\infty}\zeta b_-(\zeta)$. Then, by means of formulae [1:RP:4] and [1:RP:6], we compute the coefficients $A_D$, $B_D$ and $D_D$ of the minimal entire solution $\psi_D$. Finally, using formulae [first:ts], we compute $s$ and $t$.

heading.title: Proof of Theorem 3

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Proof of Theorem 3 / Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem
text: ### Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem The leading term of the asymptotics of $G$ being independent of $z$, the analysis of the Riemann-Hilbert problem is elementary. Assume that $\lambda$, $z$ and $p$ satisfy assumptions of Proposition 8. Let $$G_0=\frac{2i\sin(2\pi p)}{w_0}\,\begin{pmatrix} 0& F(1/2-p)\\ % F(p) & 0\end{pmatrix},\quad\quad T=\begin{pmatrix} \tau &0\\ 0 & \tau^{-1}\end{pmatrix},\quad \tau=e^{\frac{2\pi \xi p}h}.$$ Relation [F1F2:rel] implies that $\det G_0=1/w_0^2$. In view of Proposition 8, we have $$\label{G:fact} G=T\,G_0\,(I+\Delta)\,T^{-1},\quad \Delta=O(\lambda^\beta H).$$ The term $\Delta$ is analytic in $(z,p)\in \{|y|\le \frac{Y}2\}\times \{p\in P\,:\,h/4\le {\rm Re}\,p\le 1/2-h/4\}$. Now, we pass to the variable $\zeta=e^{2\pi i z/h}$. Let $\|.\|$ be a matrix norm. Pick $\alpha\in(0,1)$. For matrix functions on ${\mathbb T}=\{|\zeta|=1\}$ denote by $\|.\|_\alpha$ the standard Hölder norm defined in terms of $\|.\|$. One has

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Proof of Theorem 3 / Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem
text: **Lemma 22**. *Let $\Delta$ be a matrix-valued function on ${\mathbb T}$. If $\|\Delta\|_\alpha$ is sufficiently small, then there exist unique matrix functions $W_\pm$ such that $$\begin{gathered} \nonumber W_+ \text{ is analytic in } {\mathbb B}_o,\\ \nonumber W_-\text{ is analytic in } {\mathbb B}_\infty ,\quad W_-(\infty)=I,\\ \label{I+Delta:fact} W_+(\zeta)=(I+\Delta(\zeta))\,W_-(\zeta),\quad \zeta\in{\mathbb T}. \end{gathered}$$ These functions satisfy the estimates: $$\label{Wpm:est} \|W_+(\zeta)-I\|\le C\|\Delta\|_\alpha,\quad |\zeta|\le 1;\quad\quad % \|W_-(\zeta)-I\|\le \frac{C\|\Delta\|_\alpha}{|\zeta|},\quad |\zeta|\ge 1.$$*

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Proof of Theorem 3 / Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem
text: *Proof.* The Lemma follows from standard results of the theory of singular integral operators, see, e.g., . So, we describe the proof omitting standard details. First, in $H_\alpha({\mathbb T})$, the space of matrix-valued Hölder functions on $\mathbb T$, one constructs a solution to the equation $$\label{eq:W} W_-=I+S(\,\Delta W_-),$$ where, for $f\in H_\alpha(\mathbb T)$, $$S(f)(\zeta)=-\frac12 \,f(\zeta)+\frac1{2\pi i}\;v.p.\int_{\mathbb T} \frac{f(\zeta')\,d\zeta'}{\zeta'-\zeta},\qquad \zeta\in{\mathbb T},$$ and the orientation of $\mathbb T$ is positive. As $S$ is a bounded operator in $H_\alpha(\mathbb T)$, and as for $f,g\in H_\alpha(\mathbb T)$ one has $\|fg\|_\alpha\le \|f\|_\alpha\|g\|_\alpha$, equation [eq:W] has a unique solution provided $\|\Delta\|_\alpha$ is sufficiently small. One defines $W_+(\zeta)$ for $\zeta\in {\mathbb B}_o$ and $W_-(\zeta)$ for $\zeta\in {\mathbb B}_\infty$ by the formulas $$W_\pm(\zeta)=I+ \frac1{2\pi i} \int_{\mathbb T} \frac{\Delta(\zeta')W_-(\zeta')}{\zeta'-\zeta}\, d\zeta',$$ and checks that these two function have all the properties described in Lemma 22. We omit further details. ◻

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Proof of Theorem 3 / Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem
text: In our case, in the ring $e^{-\pi Y/h}\le|\zeta|\le e^{\pi Y/h}$,  $\Delta$ is analytic and satisfies the estimate $\|\Delta(\zeta)\|\le H\lambda^\beta$. Therefore, for any fixed $\alpha\in(0,1)$, one has $\|\Delta\|_\alpha\le C(\alpha)\,H\lambda^\beta$. So, there is a $C>0$ such that if $\lambda\le e^{-C/h}$, then $\Delta$ satisfies the assumptions of Lemma 22. For this $\Delta$, we construct $W_\pm$ by Lemma 22. The vector-valued functions defined by the formulas $$\label{Vpm:answer} V_+(\zeta)= TG_0W_+(\zeta)T^{-1}e,\quad V_-(\zeta)= T W_-(\zeta)T^{-1} e,\quad e=\frac1{B_{\psi,0}^*}\,\begin{pmatrix} 1\\0\end{pmatrix},$$ are a solution of the Riemann-Hilbert problem [1:RP:a]–[1:RP:b]. Indeed, $V_+$ is analytic in $\mathbb B_0$,  $V_-$ is analytic in $\mathbb B_\infty$, and $V_-(\infty)= T W_-(\infty) T^{-1} e=e$. Moreover, by [G:fact] and [I+Delta:fact], for $|\zeta|=1$, $$\begin{aligned} V_+(\zeta)&=T G_0 W_+(\zeta)T^{-1} e= T G_0 (I+\Delta(\zeta)) W_-(\zeta)T^{-1} e=\\ &=T G_0 (I+\Delta(\zeta))T^{-1} V_-(\zeta)=G(\zeta) V_-(\zeta). \end{aligned}$$ We compute the coefficients $s$ and $t$ of the monodromy matrix using [1:RP:4]–[1:RP:6], where $a_\pm$ and $b_\pm$ are the first and the second components of the vectors $V_\pm(0)$. Formulas [Vpm:answer], formula for $B_{\psi,0}$ from [A0,B0] and the estimate for $W_--I$ from [Wpm:est] imply that $$\label{eq:a-b-} a_-(\infty)=\frac1{B_{\psi,0}^*},\qquad b_{-,1}=\zeta b_-(\zeta)\Big|_{\zeta=\infty}=O(\lambda^\beta e^{-4\pi \xi p/h+\pi\xi}H).$$ Using also formula [w+] for $w_0$ and the estimate $\varkappa_0=O(H\lambda)$ (following from the third point of Proposition 7), we get $$\label{a+,b+} a_+(0)=O\left(e^{\pi\xi}\lambda^\beta H\right),\quad b_+(0)=\frac{e^{-\frac{4\pi\xi p}h}}{w_0B_{\psi,0}^*}\left(2i\sin(2\pi p)F(p)+ O(\lambda^\beta H)\right).$$

text: *Proof.* First, we note that $G_{12}$ was already computed when proving Proposition 8: when computing it we assumed that $0\le {\rm Re}\,p\le 1/2-h/4$, and now, as $0[G:r-an] and [w+]. So we only have to compute $G_{11}=g_{11}/w_+$ and $G_{21}=g_{21}/w_+$. Using formulas [psi-plus:2], [phi-plus:1] and [0:down], and estimates [est:a0] and [est:a_0], we get $$\begin{gathered} % \label{g11:temp0} % g_{11}=e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\; 2i\sin(2\pi p)\,e^{-\frac{i\pi(1/2-p)}h}a^*(-p)a(1/2-p) +O((1+|\xi|) \lambda^\beta H), \\ \nonumber g_{21}=e^{-\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\left(2i\sin(2\pi p)\,(|a(p)|^2-e^{\frac{8\pi p\xi}h}|a(-p)|^2) +O(\lambda^\beta(1+|\xi|) H)\right). % \end{gathered}$$ By means of [a(p,h)] and [sigma:qp], we transform [g11:temp0] to the form $$\label{g11:temp1} g_{11}=e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\,F_d(p)+O(H\lambda^{\beta}(1+|\xi|)).$$ Furthermore, the definition of $F_a$ and relation [eq:F-a] allows to get the formula $$\label{g21:temp1} g_{21}=e^{-\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\left(F_a(p)+O(\lambda^\beta(1+|\xi|) H)\right).$$ Estimates [F:1,3,4:est] follow from [est:a0] and [est:a_0]. As we can assume that $\beta$ in formulas [g11:temp1] and [g21:temp1] is larger than in Proposition 9, these formulas, [w+] and estimates [F:1,3,4:est] imply the representations for $G_{11}$ and $G_{12}$ from Proposition 9. This completes its proof. ◻

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Asymptotics of *s* and *t* for *p* close to zero / Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem
text: ### Solving the Riemann-Hilbert problem Let $$\label{G0:0} G_0=\frac1{w_0}\,\begin{pmatrix} % e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\,F_d(p)& 2iF(1/2-p)\,\sin (2\pi p) \\ % F_a(p) & e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}\,F_d^*(p). \end{pmatrix}$$ First, we prove that again $\det(G_0)=1/w_0^2$. This follows from [G0:0], the definitions of $F_a$ and $F_d$, see [F_a] and [F_d], and Lemma 21. Then, we prove that $G$ admits again representation [G:fact] with the new $G_0$. For this, using the estimates for $F_d$ and $F_a$ from [F:1,3,4:est] and the estimate for $F$ from Proposition 9, we check that $G_0^{-1}T^{-1}GT=I+O(\lambda^{\beta} H)$. Having obtained [G:fact], we proceed as in the case where $h/4\le {\rm Re}\,p$ and obtain $$\begin{gathered} \label{a+,b+:0} a_+(0)=\frac{e^{\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}F_d(p)+ O(\lambda^{\beta}H)}{w_0B_{\psi,0}^*},\quad % b_+(0)=\frac{e^{-\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}(F_a(p)+ O(\lambda^{\beta}H))}{w_0B_{\psi,0}^*},\\ \label{a-,b-:0} a_-(\infty)=\frac1{B_{\psi,0}^*},\qquad b_{-,1}=O(e^{-\frac{4\pi p\xi}h+\pi\xi}\lambda^{\beta}H). \end{gathered}$$

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Asymptotics of *s* and *t* for *p* close to zero / Asymptotics of $s$ and $t$
text: ### Asymptotics of $s$ and $t$ Computing the coefficients $s$ and $t$ by means of formulas [ts:ne0], [a+,b+:0], and [a-,b-:0], and estimates [F:1,3,4:est], we get $$t=e^{\frac{4\pi(1/2-p)\xi}h}\,\left(F_a(p)+O(\lambda^{\beta}H)\right),\quad % s=\frac{e^{\frac{2\pi i p}h+\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}} {F_a(p)+ ie^{\frac{3\pi i}{4h}+\frac{8\pi p\xi}h}F_d(p)+O(\lambda^\beta H)}.$$ Let us prove [eq:st:0] for $t$. In view of [F_1,F_2], [eq:sigma], [def:F0] and [F_a], one has $$\begin{gathered} 4\sin^2(2\pi p) F(p)=F_0(p),\ \frac{F(-p)}{F(p)}=\frac{F_0(-p)}{F_0(p)}=\rho(p),\ % F_a(p)=iF_0(p)\frac{1-\rho(p)e^{\frac{8\pi p\xi}h}}{2\sin(2\pi p)}. \end{gathered}$$ As $1/2-{\rm Re}\,p\ge 1/2-h/4\ge h/4$, formula [F1F2:rel] and the estimate for $F$ from Proposition 8 imply that $1/F_0(p)=O(H)$. This and the last formulas for $t$ and $F_a$ imply the formula for $t$ from [eq:st:0].

section_path: Asymptotics of the monodromy matrix / Asymptotics of *s* and *t* for *p* close to zero / Asymptotics of $s$ and $t$
text: Computing the coefficients $s$ and $t$ by means of formulas [ts:ne0], [a+,b+:0], and [a-,b-:0], and estimates [F:1,3,4:est], we get $$t=e^{\frac{4\pi(1/2-p)\xi}h}\,\left(F_a(p)+O(\lambda^{\beta}H)\right),\quad % s=\frac{e^{\frac{2\pi i p}h+\frac{4\pi p\xi}h}} {F_a(p)+ ie^{\frac{3\pi i}{4h}+\frac{8\pi p\xi}h}F_d(p)+O(\lambda^\beta H)}.$$ Let us prove [eq:st:0] for $t$. In view of [F_1,F_2], [eq:sigma], [def:F0] and [F_a], one has $$\begin{gathered} 4\sin^2(2\pi p) F(p)=F_0(p),\ \frac{F(-p)}{F(p)}=\frac{F_0(-p)}{F_0(p)}=\rho(p),\ % F_a(p)=iF_0(p)\frac{1-\rho(p)e^{\frac{8\pi p\xi}h}}{2\sin(2\pi p)}. \end{gathered}$$ As $1/2-{\rm Re}\,p\ge 1/2-h/4\ge h/4$, formula [F1F2:rel] and the estimate for $F$ from Proposition 8 imply that $1/F_0(p)=O(H)$. This and the last formulas for $t$ and $F_a$ imply the formula for $t$ from [eq:st:0]. The last formula for $s$ and the relation $$F_a(p)+ie^{\frac{3\pi i}{4h}+\frac{8\pi p\xi}h}F_d(p)=iF_0(p)\frac{1-e^{\frac{8\pi p}h(\xi+\frac{i}2)}\rho(p)}{2\sin(2\pi p)}.$$ imply the formula for $s$ from [eq:st:0]. The proof of Theorem 10 is complete. 0◻

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function
text: # A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function Here, following mostly , we discuss equation [eq:sigma] with $a\in(0,\pi)$.

heading.title: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Definition and elementary properties
text: ## Definition and elementary properties

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Definition and elementary properties
text: ### In $S_0=\{|x|<\pi+a\}$, equation [eq:sigma] has a unique solution $\sigma_a$ that is analytic, nonvanishing, and having the representations $$\begin{gathered} \label{sigma:down} \sigma_a(z)=1+o(e^{-\alpha|y|}), \quad y\to-\infty, \\ \nonumber \sigma_a(z)= e^{\textstyle -\frac{iz^2}{4a}+\frac{i\pi^2}{12a}+\frac{ia}{12}+o\,(e^{-\alpha|y|})}, \quad y\to+\infty, \end{gathered}$$ for any fixed $\alpha\in(0,1)$. These representations are uniform in $x$. If $a$ is bounded away from zero, they are also uniform in $a$. The function $\sigma_a$ is continuous in $a$.

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Definition and elementary properties
text: ### Using equation [eq:sigma], one can analytically continue $\sigma_a$ to a meromorphic function. Its poles are located at the points $$-\pi-a -2\pi l-2ak,\quad l,k=0,\,1,\,2,\,\dots,$$ and its zeros are at the points $$\pi+a +2\pi l+2ak,\quad l,k=0,\,1,\,2,\,\dots.$$ Its zero at $\pi+a$ and its pole at $-\pi-a$ are simple.

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Definition and elementary properties
text:
###

The function $\sigma_a$ satisfies the following relations: $$\begin{gathered}
\label{sigma:qp}
\sigma_a(z+\pi)=(1+e^{\textstyle-\frac{i\pi}a\,z})\,\sigma_a(z-\pi),\\
%
\label{sigma:sym}
 \sigma_a(-z)\,
=e^{\textstyle-\frac{i}{4a}\,z^2+\frac{i\pi^2}{12a}+
\frac{ia}{12}}\,\frac1{\sigma_a\,(z)},\\
%
\label{sigma:real-an}
\overline{\sigma_a(\overline{z})}=e^{\textstyle
\frac{i}{4a}\,z^2-\frac{i\pi^2}{12a}-
\frac{ia}{12}}\,\sigma_a\,(z).
\end{gathered}$$

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Definition and elementary properties
text:
###

One also has $$\label{sigma:res}
 {\rm Res}_{z=-\pi-a} \sigma_a=-i\sigma_a(-\pi+a)=
\sqrt{\frac a\pi}\,e^{\textstyle-\frac{i\pi^2}{12a}-\frac{i\pi}4
-\frac{ia}{12}}.$$

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Quasiclassical asymptotics
text:
## Quasiclassical asymptotics Here, we discuss $\sigma_a$ for small $a$. Thanks to [sigma:sym], it suffices to study this function for $y\le 0$. Below we use the branch of the function $z\mapsto\ln\,(1+e^{\textstyle-iz})$ analytic in ${\mathbb C}_-$, the lower halfplane, and satisfying the condition $$% \ln\,(1+e^{\textstyle-iz})\to 0,\quad y\to-\infty.$$ We set $$% L(z)=\int_{-i\infty}^{z}\ln\,(1+e^{\textstyle-iz'})\,dz',$$ where we integrate in ${\mathbb C}_-$, say, along the line ${\rm Re}\,z'={\rm Re}\,z$.
**Theorem 11**. * Pick $0<\delta<\pi$. In ${\mathbb C}_-\cup\mathbb R$ outside the $\delta$-neighborhood of the half-lines $z\ge \pi$ and $z\le -\pi$, for sufficiently small $a$,  $\sigma_a$ admits the representation $$\label{Pi} \sigma_a(z)=\exp\left(\frac1{2a} L(z)+ O\left(\,a\,(1+|x|)e^{-|y|}\,\right)\right).$$*
Let us discuss the behavior of $\sigma_a$ in a neighborhood of the point $-\pi$.
**Theorem 12**. * Let $0<\delta<2\pi$. For $t$ in the $\delta$-neighborhood of zero, one has $$\label{theta:delta} \sigma_a(-\pi+t)=\frac{e^{\frac{\ln(2a)}{2a} t}}{\sqrt{2\pi}} \Gamma\left(\frac{t+a}{2a}\right)\, e^{\frac1{2a}\,\int_0^t\tilde l(\zeta) d\zeta-\frac{i\pi^2}{6a}+ O\left(a\right)}, \quad \tilde l(\zeta)=\ln\frac{1-e^{-i\zeta}}{\zeta},$$ where $\tilde l$ is analytic, and $\tilde l(0)=i\pi/2$. The error term in [theta:delta] is analytic in $t$.*

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Uniform estimates
text:
## Uniform estimates Fix $\delta\in(0,\pi)$ and $\kappa\in(0,1)$.
**Corollary 9**. *Outside the $\delta$-neighborhood of the ray $z<-\pi$, one has $$\begin{gathered} \label{rough-est:down} \sigma_a(z)=e^{O\left(a^{-1}e^{-\kappa |y|}(1+|x|)\right)},\quad y\le 0,\\ \label{rough-est:up} \sigma_a\,(z)=e^{ -\frac{iz^2}{4a}+\frac{i\pi^2}{12a}+ \frac{ia}{12}+O\left(a^{-1}e^{-\kappa |y|}(1+|x|)\right) }, \quad y\ge 0. \end{gathered}$$*

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Uniform estimates
text: *Proof.* Estimate [rough-est:up] follows from [rough-est:down] and [sigma:real-an]. Let us prove [rough-est:down]. Assume that $y\le 0$. First, we note that [rough-est:down] is valid for $|x|\le a$. Indeed, let $a_0>0$ be so small that [Pi] holds for all $0[rough-est:down] follows directly from [Pi]. For $a_0\le a\le 2\pi$, it follows from [sigma:down] that is valid and uniform in $a$ and in $x$ if $|x|\le a$. Now, we assume that $z$ is outside the $\delta$-neighborhood of the ray $z<-\pi$. We choose $n\in{\mathbb Z}$ so that $|x-2an|\le a$. By [eq:sigma] $$\sigma_a(z)=\prod_{j=1}^{|n|}\left(1+e^{\textstyle-i(z\mp(2j-1)a)}\right)^{\pm1 } \sigma_a(z-2na) \quad \text{if} \quad\pm n\ge1.$$ As $|n|\le \frac{|x|}{2a}+\frac12$, we get $$\label{est:aux:1} \prod_{j=1}^{|n|}\left(1+e^{-i(z\mp(2j-1)a)}\right)^{\pm 1} =e^{O(|n|\,e^{-|y|})} =e^{O\left(xe^{-|y|}/a\right)}.$$ Formula [rough-est:down] valid for $|x|\le a$ and [est:aux:1] imply [rough-est:down] for all $z$ we consider. ◻

section_path: A trigonometric analog of the Euler Gamma-function / Uniform estimates
text:
*Proof.* Estimate [rough-est:up] follows from [rough-est:down] and [sigma:real-an]. Let us prove [rough-est:down]. Assume that $y\le 0$. First, we note that [rough-est:down] is valid for $|x|\le a$. Indeed, let $a_0>0$ be so small that [Pi] holds for all $0[rough-est:down] follows directly from [Pi]. For $a_0\le a\le 2\pi$, it follows from [sigma:down] that is valid and uniform in $a$ and in $x$ if $|x|\le a$. Now, we assume that $z$ is outside the $\delta$-neighborhood of the ray $z<-\pi$. We choose $n\in{\mathbb Z}$ so that $|x-2an|\le a$. By [eq:sigma] $$\sigma_a(z)=\prod_{j=1}^{|n|}\left(1+e^{\textstyle-i(z\mp(2j-1)a)}\right)^{\pm1 } \sigma_a(z-2na) \quad \text{if} \quad\pm n\ge1.$$ As $|n|\le \frac{|x|}{2a}+\frac12$, we get $$\label{est:aux:1} \prod_{j=1}^{|n|}\left(1+e^{-i(z\mp(2j-1)a)}\right)^{\pm 1} =e^{O(|n|\,e^{-|y|})} =e^{O\left(xe^{-|y|}/a\right)}.$$ Formula [rough-est:down] valid for $|x|\le a$ and [est:aux:1] imply [rough-est:down] for all $z$ we consider. ◻ Fix positive $c_1$, $c_2$ and $\delta<2\pi$.
**Corollary 10**. *Let $|z+\pi|\le \delta$ and $x\ge -\pi-a+c_1a-c_2|y|$. Then, $|\sigma_a(z)|\le e^{C/a}$.*
*Proof.*  *1)*  Let $u=\frac{z+\pi+a}{2a}$. Then, under the hypothesis of the corollary, $$% {\rm Re}\,u\ge \frac{c_1}2-c_2|{\rm Im}\,u|.$$ Let $D$ be the domain defined by this inequality in the complex plane of $u$. *2)*  For $u\in D$, we set $$% Y(u)=\sqrt{\frac{u}{2\pi}}\,e^{-u\,\left(\ln u- 1\right)} \Gamma(u)$$ where the branches of $\ln{.}$ and $\sqrt{.}$ are analytic in $\mathbb C\setminus\{z\le 0\}$ and such that $\ln 1=0$ and $\sqrt{1}=1$. The function $Y$ is bounded in $D$.  By [theta:delta] and the previous steps, under the hypothesis of the Corollary, $$\label{est:sigma} \begin{split}\textstyle |\sigma_a(z)|&\le C\,\left|\exp\left(u(\ln u-1)-\frac12\ln u+\frac{\ln(2a)}{2a} (z+\pi)+ \frac1{2a}\,\int_0^{z+\pi}\tilde l(\zeta) d\zeta\right)\right|\\ \textstyle &\le e^{C/a} \left|\exp\left(u\ln u+\frac{\ln(2a)}{2a}(z+\pi)\right)\right|\le e^{C/a}\left|e^{u\ln(2au)}\right|, \end{split}$$ as $\tilde l$ is analytic in the $\delta$-neighborhood of zero and as $|u|\ge C$ in $D$ . As $|2au|=|z+\pi+a|\le C$, then one also has $|2au\ln(2au)|\le C$, and [est:sigma] implies that $|\sigma_a(z)|\le e^{C/a}$. ◻
